question: For a Listed Entity that has only partially adopted the best practice standards in APP 4, what specific disclosures must appear in its annual financial report, and how does that annual reporting obligation align with the Regulator’s expectation for disclosure in the Prospectus and thereafter under Rule 9.2.10, including the consequence of inaccurate or false representations?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity that has only partially adopted APP 4 must make a structured set of disclosures in its annual financial report, and those disclosures should be consistent with the Regulator’s expectation that the same type of explanation and alternative measures be disclosed in the Prospectus and then continued thereafter under Rule 9.2.10. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e] Specifically, the annual financial report must (i) state whether the APP 4 best practice standards (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted, and (ii) where adoption is partial, explain why full adoption did not occur and describe what actions (if any) were taken to achieve compliance to the extent of the gap. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] In addition, Directors must provide an opinion on whether the Listed Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and assumptions and including qualifications if needed. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] In parallel, where a Reporting Entity does not adopt APP 4 (or does so only partially), the Regulator expects the reasons and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the intended outcomes to be disclosed in the Prospectus and thereafter pursuant to Rule 9.2.10. [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e] Any inaccurate or false representations in these disclosures can result in civil liability under section 70 of the FSMR. [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e]
source_text: Generally, if a Reporting Entity does not adopt the best practice standards set out in APP 4, or adopts them only partially, the Regulator would expect the reasons for doing so and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the outcomes intended by the Corporate Governance Principles to be disclosed in the Prospectus and thereafter pursuant to the Disclosure required under Rule 9.2.10. Any inaccurate or false representations would lead to the imposition of civil liability in accordance with section 70 of the FSMR.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s later disclosure refers to earlier estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves and also includes such estimates in the later disclosure, what specific confirmations and cross-references are required, and what Competent Person identification details must be stated in that disclosure?
gold_answer: Where a later disclosure refers to earlier estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, the Mining Reporting Entity must reference the earlier disclosure that was compliant with Rule 11.12.1 in order for Rule 11.12.1 to be treated as applying only the first time. [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] It must also confirm that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure(s). [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] Because the subject matter is estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, the later disclosure must further confirm that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the earlier estimates continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] Separately, because the later disclosure contains estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves (and the rule also covers Exploration Targets and Exploration Results), it must state that the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] It must also state, for each Competent Person, whether they are an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party, and if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer, and it must identify the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]
source_text:
Competent Persons . Rule 11.12.1 only applies the first time a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results in accordance with Rule 11.4 or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with Rules 11.5 or 11.6 provided that:
(1)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to those Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.12.1; and
(2)	the Mining Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure(s) and, in the case of estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure(s) continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: When considering whether to support or give full effect to a Foreign Resolution Action by exercising Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers (including any need for ex-ante judicial approval under section 27), in what circumstances may the Regulator refuse to recognise the Foreign Resolution Action in whole or in part?
gold_answer: The Regulator may decline to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (in full or only for certain parts) even where the contemplated next step would be to support or give full effect to it through the use of Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers (and even if ex-ante judicial approval under section 27 would otherwise be relevant to that exercise). [#TGT:5798f720-7021-4b63-9ebe-f1a30aebee29] Refusal is available if the Regulator is satisfied that at least one specified condition applies. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Those conditions include: recognition would harm financial stability in the ADGM; the Resolution Conditions have not been met for the relevant entity listed in section 2 in connection with the Regulator’s proposed Resolution Action under section 78(5); or Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch under section 78(5) is not needed to meet one or more Resolution Objectives. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] The Regulator may also refuse recognition if the foreign action would treat creditors located or payable in the ADGM differently (in treatment or legal rights) solely because of their ADGM location compared with creditors (including depositors) in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Finally, refusal is permitted where recognition and supportive action would have material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]
target_text: For the purposes of supporting, or giving full effect to, a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may exercise one or more Resolution Tools, or one or more Resolution Powers, subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval in compliance with section 27.

question: If the Investigator sends a written notice telling the Person Under Investigation (or someone else) to let the Investigator into their business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy Documents, does the Investigator have to warn them ahead of time that an inspection is coming?
gold_answer: No. The Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to permit the Investigator to enter that person’s business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy Documents there [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Separately, for the power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents, the Investigator will give written notice of the exercise of that power, but there is no requirement for the Investigator to give that notice in advance [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980]. This means the Investigator can carry out an inspection without giving prior warning, even though written notice is still part of how the power is exercised [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980]. The passage also explains why advance notice might be withheld: there may be circumstances where the Investigator considers it appropriate not to provide prior notice, such as where giving prior notice may prejudice the investigation [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980]. Taken together, the Investigator can require access by written notice and still choose not to provide advance notice of the inspection itself [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].
source_text: Power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents . The Investigator will give written notice of the exercise of the power to enter business premises under section 206(1)(e) of FSMR. However, there is no requirement for an Investigator to give notice of the exercise of this power in advance. There may be circumstances when the Investigator considers it appropriate not to provide prior notice of an inspection, for example where the provision of prior notice may prejudice the investigation.

question: When may deferred publication of transaction information be authorised for a large transaction, and how must the firm determine whether the transaction meets the relevant minimum qualifying size by using the ADT-based thresholds and permitted delays table?
gold_answer: Deferred publication may be authorised only where the trade is between a Member (or, where applicable, an Authorised Person) acting on own account and that firm’s Client, and the transaction size is at or above the relevant minimum qualifying size for the instrument and transaction. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] To determine whether the size condition is met, the firm must first classify the Financial Instrument (admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange) by its average daily turnover (ADT) calculated under the Rule 3.6.10 methodology, and then apply the table’s ADT band and the chosen permitted publication delay to identify the corresponding minimum qualifying size threshold. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] The table links each permitted delay (e.g., 60 minutes, 180 minutes, until end of trading day, or later trading-day-based delays) to ADT ranges and specifies the minimum qualifying size as either a fixed amount, a percentage of ADT, or a max/min expression depending on the ADT band. [#TGT:096764ad-3a3c-4347-9345-61ad740d7e27] Any authorisation for deferred publication cannot extend beyond the maximum deferral period specified for the relevant class of Financial Instrument and transaction. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48]
source_text:
Deferred publication of large transactions
The deferred publication of information in respect of transactions may be authorised, for a period no longer than the period specified in Rule ‎3.6.10 for the class of Financial Instrument and transaction concerned, provided the following criteria are satisfied:
(a)	the transaction is between a Member or if applicable, Authorised Person, dealing on own account and a Client of that firm; and
(b)	the size of that transaction is equal to or exceeds the relevant minimum qualifying size, as specified in Rule 3.6.10. In order to determine the relevant minimum qualifying size, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange shall be classified in accordance with their average daily turnover to be calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6.10.

question: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, how should it treat the exposure measure in its credit risk calculation when (i) the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15 and (ii) the SFT is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA (including where supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts are used)?
gold_answer: In this combined scenario, the Authorised Person may recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for the SFT when measuring the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure determined under Rule 4.9.15, but it must also apply the FCCA netting-based exposure measure for credit risk capital purposes and use that measure in place of E in the credit risk calculation. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Specifically, because the SFT is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA, it must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty that are covered by that qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, following Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 (including the case where supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts are used). [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] After calculating E*, the Authorised Person must substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8. [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] In parallel, for the same SFT where eligible financial Collateral has been taken and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15, the effect of that Collateral may be recognised in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty covered by the qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 (if the Authorised Person is using supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts), and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8.

question: When applying the corporate asset class risk-weight table, how must an Authorised Person treat an unrated CR Exposure (long term or short term) to a corporate if a short term issue-specific external credit assessment for that corporate attracts a 150% risk weight, and how does this interact with the table’s unrated risk weight?
gold_answer: The corporate risk-weight table provides an unrated risk weight for corporate-asset-class CR Exposures, but a specific rule requires a higher risk weight in the stated 150% scenario. [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4] If a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class has an issue-specific external credit assessment that attracts a 150% risk weight, the Authorised Person must apply a 150% risk weight to any unrated CR Exposure to the same corporate, regardless of whether that unrated exposure is long term or short term. [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad] This requirement effectively overrides the table’s unrated row (which otherwise indicates 100% for unrated corporate exposures) for exposures to that same corporate once the triggering 150% short term assessed exposure exists. [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4] [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad] The operational consequence is that the Authorised Person cannot default to the table’s unrated risk weight in this case; instead, the unrated exposure must be aligned to 150% because the assessed short term exposure signals that higher risk weight for the corporate. [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad] The table remains relevant as the general framework for corporate risk weights, but the specific 150% linkage rule governs the unrated exposures to the same corporate in this defined circumstance. [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4] [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad]
source_text:
Corporate asset class. The risk weight for any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class that does not have an external credit assessment by a recognised external credit rating agency must be the risk weight determined in accordance with the table under Rule 4.12.13 or the risk weight that is applicable to an CR Exposure to the central government of the jurisdiction in which the corporate is incorporated or established, whichever is higher. If a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue specific external credit assessment:
(a)	attracts a risk weight of 50% or 100%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of not lower than 100% to any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate; or
(b)	attracts a risk weight of 150%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of 150% to any unrated CR Exposure (whether long term or short term) to the same corporate.

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange admits a Financial Instrument to trading and it uses a benchmark or index from a Price Reporting Agency, what checks must the exchange do to make sure the Price Reporting Agency meets the required standards?
gold_answer: If a Recognised Investment Exchange is admitting to trading a Financial Instrument that references an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency, the exchange must carry out appropriate due diligence to ensure the Price Reporting Agency meets the relevant requirements [#SRC:69082061-a103-4087-acae-fa41e87fd0da]. In practical terms, the checks must cover whether the Price Reporting Agency has fair, non-discriminatory procedures for establishing prices and whether those procedures are made public; and whether it can demonstrate adequate transparency over its methodology, calculation, and inputs so users can understand how the benchmark or index is derived and what its potential limitations are [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. The exchange should also assess whether, where appropriate, the Price Reporting Agency gives priority to concluded transactions and has measures to minimise selective reporting; whether it is of good standing and repute as an independent and objective price reporting agency or index provider; and whether it has a sound corporate governance framework [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. The due diligence must further consider whether the Price Reporting Agency has adequate arrangements to avoid staff conflicts of interest that could materially adversely affect the price establishment process, and whether it maintains adequate complaint resolution mechanisms for its assessment process and methodology [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a].
source_text: When admitting to trading a Financial Instrument that references an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency, a Recognised Investment Exchange must undertake appropriate due diligence to ensure that the Price Reporting Agency meets the requirements in Rule 3.11.2.

question: If an Authorised Person is working out how much of a Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital can count in consolidated T1 Capital, what does it do with the 8.0% requirement tied to Total Risk Exposure Amount, and what items make up that Total Risk Exposure Amount?
gold_answer: To decide how much of a Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital can be counted in consolidated T1 Capital, the Authorised Person must start with the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital and then reduce it using a formula that depends on an 8.0% T1 Capital requirement based on Total Risk Exposure Amount. [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14] The reduction is calculated by multiplying two inputs and subtracting the result: (1) an amount that is the lesser of (i) the Subsidiary’s solo 8.0% T1 Capital requirement on its Total Risk Exposure Amount plus its Combined Buffer Requirement, or (ii) the amount of consolidated T1 Capital relating to the Subsidiary needed on a consolidated basis to meet the Financial Group’s 8.0% T1 Capital requirement on Total Risk Exposure Amount plus its Combined Buffer Requirement; and (2) the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital expressed as a percentage of all its T1 Capital instruments plus related retained earnings and Share premium accounts. [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used in those 8.0% calculations must be computed (after taking into account Rule 3.5.8) by adding together: Credit RWA, and the Risk Exposure Amounts for Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and (if applicable) Displaced Commercial Risk (calculated in accordance with IFR Rule 5.4.5). [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]
source_text:
Qualifying T1 Capital instruments included in consolidated T1 Capital. An Authorised Person must determine the amount of qualifying T1 Capital of a Subsidiary that is included in consolidated T1 Capital of the Authorised Person's Financial Group by subtracting from the qualifying T1 Capital of that Subsidiary the result of multiplying the amount referred to in (a) by the percentage referred to in (b):
(a)	the lesser of the following:
(i)	the amount of T1 Capital of that Subsidiary required to meet the sum of the Subsidiary's T1 Capital requirement (on a solo basis) of 8.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	the amount of consolidated T1 Capital that relates to the Subsidiary that is required on a consolidated basis to meet the sum of its Financial Group's T1 Capital requirement of 8.0% of the Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and its Combined Buffer Requirement;
(b)	the qualifying T1 Capital of the Subsidiary expressed as a percentage of all T1 Capital instruments of that Subsidiary plus the related retained earnings and Share premium accounts.

question: If an Authorised Person sells some of its HQLA during a financial or liquidity stress period to get cash for outflows, and this means it may not meet its LCR Requirement, what must it tell the Regulator and how quickly?
gold_answer: In a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person is allowed to liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows, even if that means its HQLA level falls below what is required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with those outflows [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f]. But if the Authorised Person does not meet its LCR Requirement, or if it becomes aware of circumstances from the stress situation that may result in it not meeting its LCR Requirement, it must notify the Regulator in writing immediately [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c]. This applies “at any time” and specifically includes stress periods, so the fact that selling HQLA is permitted to manage outflows does not delay or replace the duty to send immediate written notice when the LCR Requirement is breached or is at risk of being breached [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f] [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c].
source_text: Liquidation of assets during periods of stress . During a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person may liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows. Subject to Rule 9.3.9, the Authorised Person's level of HQLA may fall below the levels required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with cash outflows during that period.
target_text: Notification if LCR Requirement is not met . An Authorised Person must notify the Regulator in writing immediately if it does not meet, or becomes aware of circumstances that may result in it not meeting, at any time, its LCR Requirement (including during a period of stress referred to in Rule 9.3.8).

question: If an Authorised Person does not meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, what must it do before it can pay a cash dividend or issue bonus Shares, and why do those actions count as a CET1 Capital distribution?
gold_answer: Cash dividends and the distribution of fully or partly paid bonus Shares (or other capital instruments) are both included in what counts as a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26]. So, when an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must first calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with the applicable rule. Until it has calculated that amount and notified the Regulator under the required notification rule, it must ensure it does not undertake a CET1 Capital distribution, which would include paying a cash dividend or issuing bonus Shares [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. In the same period (before calculation and notification), it must also ensure it does not create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, and it must not pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. It must also avoid making payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments until the required steps are completed [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].
target_text:
Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and
(b)	ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7:
(i)	make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange wants to admit a Financial Instrument to trading and that instrument uses a benchmark or index from a Price Reporting Agency, what checks does the exchange need to do, and what things must the Price Reporting Agency have in place?
gold_answer: The Recognised Investment Exchange must do appropriate due diligence when it admits to trading a Financial Instrument that references a benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency, and the purpose of that due diligence is to ensure the agency meets the requirements in Rule 3.11.2. [#SRC:69082061-a103-4087-acae-fa41e87fd0da] To meet those requirements, the Price Reporting Agency must satisfy the listed conditions that apply for the purposes of Rules 3.11.1 and 3.11.3. [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a] The exchange’s checks therefore need to confirm, at least, that the agency: has fair and non-discriminatory price-setting procedures that are made public; provides enough transparency about its methodology, calculations, and inputs for users to understand how the benchmark or index is produced and what its limits are; and, where appropriate, gives priority to concluded transactions and reduces selective reporting. [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a] The due diligence should also cover whether the agency is independent and reputable, has sound corporate governance, has arrangements to prevent staff conflicts of interest that could materially harm the price establishment process, and has adequate mechanisms to resolve complaints about its assessment process and methodology. [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a] These checks are required specifically because the exchange is admitting an instrument that relies on the agency’s benchmark or index. [#SRC:69082061-a103-4087-acae-fa41e87fd0da]
source_text: When admitting to trading a Financial Instrument that references an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency, a Recognised Investment Exchange must undertake appropriate due diligence to ensure that the Price Reporting Agency meets the requirements in Rule 3.11.2.

question: How should a PFP Operator align its pre-publication review of a PFP Prospect’s management fitness/propriety and the PFP Prospect’s financial soundness/good standing with the requirement to publish the criteria/methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication, and what additional due-diligence-related disclosure must be made available to PFP Clients?
gold_answer: The PFP Operator should ensure that the acceptance criteria and methodology it publishes to PFP Clients are consistent with the specific pre-publication due diligence it is required to perform on a PFP Prospect, and it must also disclose how that due diligence is conducted and where it is limited. [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] Before publishing a financing proposal, the PFP Operator’s due diligence must include reviewing information from the PFP Prospect about: management details and background (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers) and the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing, and regulatory status if relevant). [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] Because the platform must also publish the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication, those published acceptance criteria should reflect that these management and background checks form part of the operator’s review before a proposal is made available on the platform. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] In addition, the PFP Operator must publish to PFP Clients the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence it undertakes concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the platform, so clients understand the scope and boundaries of the operator’s review. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]
source_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: When a Listed Entity has only partially adopted the best practice standards in APP 4, what combined annual-reporting disclosures are required regarding (i) reasons and actions for that partial adoption and (ii) the Board/Directors’ opinion on the Corporate Governance framework’s effectiveness, including the additional effectiveness outcome that must be covered under Rule 9.2.10?
gold_answer: Where APP 4 best practice standards are only partially adopted, the annual financial report must explain why full adoption did not occur and describe what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent of the gap. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Alongside that adoption narrative, the report must include a statement by Directors giving their opinion on whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and assumptions and with qualifications if necessary. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] To align with the annual report statement required under Rule 9.2.10, the Board’s statement must also cover whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR, not only promoting compliance with the Principles. [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca] The supporting material should reflect that the Principles are the core of the Corporate Governance framework and that their application is the central question for the Board in determining how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs under its directorship in accordance with the applicable requirements. [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca] Taken together, the partial-adoption explanations and the effectiveness opinion should be coherent and grounded in the entity’s described governance approach. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca]
source_text: General. The annual report required under Rule 9.2.10 must include a statement by the Board of Directors (the "Board"), stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR and promoting compliance with the Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary. As the Principles are the core of the Corporate Governance framework, the way in which they are applied should be the central question for the Board as it determines how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs under its directorship in accordance with the letter and spirit of the applicable requirements including the Principles and the standards.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target and also discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, what specific categories of assumptions and other key supporting information must be included to satisfy both disclosure obligations?
gold_answer: Where a Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, it must include comprehensive information about the assumptions used to determine that forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions employed, any statement that such material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive (if the Mining Reporting Entity considers them so) together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine them, and all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In addition, the disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required to accompany that Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Separately, when the Mining Reporting Entity discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure must also include key information relating to mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status, and the relative accuracy/confidence [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129]. Read together, the combined disclosure package must cover both the forecast-related assumption set (economic and other material assumptions plus the Production Target basis) and the Ore Reserves-specific technical and confidence information [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Rule 11.6 also requires that when a Mining Reporting Entity discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure is also to include key information relating to mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status and the relative accuracy/confidence.

question: When an Authorised Person intends to recognise the effects of CRM using Collateral, what must it do to ensure the relevant recognition conditions are satisfied, including the legal enforceability and liquidation rights needed before recognition?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must not recognise the effects of CRM using Collateral unless it ensures the applicable recognition requirements are complied with [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8]. In practice, this means confirming, before recognition, that the legal mechanism used to pledge, assign, or transfer the Collateral gives the Authorised Person a timely right to liquidate or take legal possession upon the Counterparty’s default, insolvency, bankruptcy, or other defined credit events (and, where relevant, similar events affecting a custodian) [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]. The Authorised Person must also have taken all steps needed under the applicable law to obtain and maintain an enforceable security interest (including registration where required) or to exercise netting or set-off rights for title transfer Collateral. Additionally, it must ensure there is no material positive correlation between the Counterparty’s credit quality and the Collateral’s value, exclude securities issued by the Counterparty or any Closely Related Counterparty, implement procedures for timely liquidation that observe legal conditions for declaring default and liquidating, and, where a custodian holds the Collateral, take reasonable steps to ensure segregation from the custodian’s own assets [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1].
source_text:
Collateral
In order to recognise the effects of CRM of the types of Collateral set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person must ensure that the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with.

question: Before putting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal on its Private Financing Platform, what checks must the PFP Operator do, and what must it publish for PFP Clients about the risks and about how its due diligence works (including any limits)?
gold_answer: The PFP Operator must carry out due diligence on the PFP Prospect before it publishes a financing proposal relating to that PFP Prospect. That due diligence must include reviewing: (1) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (2) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing and (where relevant) regulatory status; and (3) the financing proposal itself, so that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the proposal content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. Separately, the PFP Operator must make sure certain information is published on the Private Financing Platform and available to PFP Clients. This includes a statement identifying the risks involved in participating in financing proposals on the platform, and it also includes publishing the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence the PFP Operator undertakes for each PFP Prospect identified on the platform [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]. Read together, the rules require both (a) doing the checks before publication and (b) being transparent with PFP Clients on the platform about the risks and how the PFP Operator’s due diligence is carried out and where it may not cover everything.
source_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: If an Authorised Person is covered by this Appendix because it meets the stated criteria, when does it have to have a Trading Book based on what positions it holds, whether they are held for trading, and the dollar/percentage thresholds (including the last 12 months test)?
gold_answer: This Appendix applies to an Authorised Person that meets the referenced criteria and is thereby required to have a Trading Book [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d]. For an Authorised Person in that scope, it must have a Trading Book when the specific conditions in the obligation are met [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]. The Authorised Person must have a Trading Book if it has positions that must be included in a Trading Book under Section A2.1 of App2, and those positions are held with trading intent under Rule A2.1.5. It also has to meet a size threshold based on the total value of positions eligible for inclusion in the Trading Book under those two conditions. That threshold is met if the value normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on and off balance sheet positions, or if it has exceeded $20 million or 6% of its combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 month period. If these elements line up, the Trading Book is required.
source_text: This Appendix applies to an Authorised Person which meets the criteria in Rule 2.2.1 and is thereby required to have a Trading Book.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must have a Trading Book if:
(a)	it has positions that must be included in a Trading Book in accordance with Section A2.1 of App2;
(b)	those positions are held with trading intent in accordance with Rule A2.1.5; and
(c)	the total value of the positions eligible for inclusion in the Trading Book pursuant to (a) and (b):
(i)	normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on and off balance sheet positions; or
(ii)	has exceeded $20 million or 6% of its combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 month period.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, how should the required minimum systems and controls for Virtual Asset wallets and key management be integrated into the broader technology governance expectations on system maintenance/testing and third-party interfaces, so that both sets of requirements are met?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must implement documented systems and controls for Virtual Asset wallets and for private/public keys, and those controls should be embedded within a wider technology governance framework that also addresses system upkeep/testing and third-party service interfaces. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] Practically, this means the wallet and key procedures are not standalone documents; they should be maintained and evolved through disciplined system development practices (such as controlled updates, issue resolution, and regular internal and third-party testing) so the controls remain effective as the architecture changes. [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] At a minimum, the wallet procedures should cover lifecycle activities (setup/configuration/deployment/deletion/backup and recovery), access privilege and user management, rule/limit determination with review and updates, and audit/oversight, while key procedures should address generation, exchange, storage, backup, destruction, access management, public key sharing, and re-use where applicable. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] Where any wallet or key functionality relies on external providers (e.g., custody tooling, cloud services, or data/service recipients), the Authorised Person should also maintain procedures governing the creation and management of services, interfaces, and channels provided by or to third parties to ensure those dependencies are controlled. [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity prepares a disclosure under a Mining Reporting Standard, how must it address non-mandatory requirements—particularly where it does not fully comply with them—and what explanation must be included in the disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is expected to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, even though those requirements are described as non-mandatory, and this expectation sits alongside the obligation to fully comply with all binding requirements in the same standards [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]. If, in a particular disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard, it must not remain silent or rely on the non-mandatory label; instead, it must include an explicit statement within the disclosure explaining both how the disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement and why it differs [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f]. In practice, this means the disclosure should identify the specific non-mandatory requirement that is not met, describe the nature of the deviation (the “how”), and provide the rationale for the deviation (the “why”), thereby addressing the Regulator’s expectation of full compliance or a clear explanation of non-compliance [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] while satisfying the disclosure-level statement requirement [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f].
source_text: Rule 11.2.1(1) requires a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all binding requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard. The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.
target_text: Requirements for all disclosures. Where a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in a Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide in its disclosure a statement as to how and why its disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard.

question: If the Regulator gets the Rule 3.2.2 notice and normally would tell the Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days about using the passporting procedures, when is it not allowed to send the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a), and what does that mean for publishing the Passported Fund details and telling the Fund Manager registration is complete?
gold_answer: Even where the process describes a five-Business-Day step to notify Host Regulator(s) after the Regulator receives the Rule 3.2.2 notice, the Regulator is not permitted to transmit the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a) in certain situations. [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e] The Regulator must not send that notice if it believes the Fund Manager or the Public Fund is not complying with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if it has reasonable grounds to think the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may fail to comply in the future. [#SRC:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] It also must refrain if it considers holding back is necessary and appropriate to meet its objectives. [#SRC:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] If the Regulator does not transmit the Rule 3.2.4(a) notice, the later steps described in the passporting sequence cannot be reached as written, because they depend on Host Regulator action and confirmation. [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e] In particular, the Regulator’s publication of the Passported Fund details on the Register of Passported Funds and its notification to the Fund Manager that registration is complete are triggered only after the relevant Host Regulator confirms its Register has been updated to include the Passported Fund details. [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e]
source_text:
The Regulator shall not transmit a notice under Rule 3.2.4‎(a):
(a)	if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund does not comply with, or it has reasonable grounds for determining that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may in the future not comply with, applicable legislation, including these Rules; or
(b)	if it considers that it is necessary and appropriate to refrain from doing so in order to meet its objectives.
target_text:
The Regulator shall:
(a)	Within five Business Days of receipt of the notice set out in Rule 3.2.2, and subject to Rule 3.2.5, provide notice of the intent to use the passporting procedures under these Rules to the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted; and
(b)	promptly following confirmation from the relevant Host Regulator that its respective Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the details of the Passported Fund:
(i)	publish the details of the Passported Fund on the Register of Passported Funds; and
(ii)	notify the Fund Manager that registration on the Register of Passported Funds is complete.

question: When a PFP Operator uses a Body Corporate as an intermediary between a PFP Client and a PFP Prospect, what combined requirements apply to (i) publishing governance/operational arrangements and (ii) retaining transaction-related documentation, and what is the minimum retention period?
gold_answer: Where a PFP Operator uses a Body Corporate as an intermediary, it must address both transparency to PFP Clients via platform publication and documentary retention for a defined period. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] On the publication side, the PFP Operator must ensure information available to PFP Clients is published on the Private Financing Platform, including the governance and operational arrangements of any Body Corporate used as an intermediary between a PFP Client and any PFP Prospect. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] On the record-retention side, the PFP Operator must maintain and keep, for a minimum of six years, all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Read together, this means the PFP Operator should (i) publish the Body Corporate’s governance/operational arrangements for PFP Clients to review and (ii) preserve the related transaction documentation involving that Body Corporate for at least six years, so the intermediary structure described to clients is supported by a retained record of how the intermediary was used in practice. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider can agree in writing that the rule about liability for charges does not apply. If they do not make that written agreement, what must the Payment Service Provider pay the Payment Service User when the Payment Service Provider does not execute a Payment Transaction, executes it wrongly, or executes it late?
gold_answer: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider are allowed to agree in writing that certain rules will not apply, including the rule dealing with liability for charges [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. If they do not make that written agreement (or if the situation is not covered by what they agreed), the Payment Service Provider must follow the stated liability outcome for execution problems: the Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges that the Payment Service User is responsible for, and for any interest the Payment Service User must pay, when those amounts arise because the Payment Service Provider did not execute the Payment Transaction, executed it defectively, or executed it late [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa]. This means the Payment Service Provider’s obligation is tied to the consequences of its non-execution, defective execution, or late execution, and it covers both (i) charges borne by the Payment Service User and (ii) interest the Payment Service User must pay due to that failure. The written agreement option is simply a permitted way to switch off the identified rule(s) for non-Natural Person users.
target_text: A Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges for which the Payment Service User is responsible and any interest which the Payment Service User must pay as a consequence of the non-execution, defective or late execution of a Payment Transaction by the Payment Service Provider.

question: When a substantial additional regulatory burden arises for FSRA and the Regulator expects substantial additional costs or effort in handling an application, authorisation, filing, or ongoing supervision, may the Regulator require a Person (including an Applicant/Authorised Person) to pay supplementary or additional fees, and what practical step is recommended to manage the fee implications?
gold_answer: Yes. The SOURCE establishes that FSRA reserves the right to impose additional fees where a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA, and it highlights that such circumstances can include a migration of an MTF to become a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange, indicating that fee impacts may arise from increased regulatory work [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc]. The TARGET complements this by permitting the Regulator to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee when it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision, which aligns with the SOURCE’s concept of additional burden translating into additional fee recovery [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Taken together, the framework supports the Regulator’s ability to levy extra charges in high-effort or high-cost cases affecting Applicants/Authorised Persons. As a practical compliance step, FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss fee implications with FSRA as early as practicable, so potential supplementary/additional fees can be anticipated and managed in advance [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc].
source_text:
FEES
Cumulative application of Fees
Pursuant to FEES Rule 1.2.4, the FSRA reserves its right to impose additional fees in circumstances where a ‘substantial additional’ regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA. In such circumstances, including the migration of an MTF to become a conventional ‘Securities’ Recognised Investment Exchange, the FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss FEE implications with the FSRA as early as practicable.
target_text:
Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s forecast financial information comes from a Production Target for an operating mine, when can it skip complying with Rule 11.9.2, and what does it still have to put in its Rule 11.9.1 disclosure (especially if the economic assumptions are commercially sensitive)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity can avoid having to comply with Rule 11.9.2 for forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) when the forecast is wholly based on Ore Reserves, or on Ore Reserves combined with Measured Mineral Resources, or on Ore Reserves combined with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources as long as the Indicated Mineral Resources are not what determines whether the project is viable. [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7] However, where the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1, it still must include details about the assumptions used to work out the forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions and all other material assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If it believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must say they are commercially sensitive and describe the methodology it used to determine those assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include the Production Target the forecast is based on, and that Production Target must be presented with all the information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]
source_text:
A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 where the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based on:
(1)	Ore Reserves;
(2)	a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or
(3)	a combination of Ore Reserves; and
(a)	Measured Mineral Resources; and/or
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: When applying the 20% cap formula for a Listed Entity’s proposed issue or agreement to issue Equity Securities, how must the entity count Convertible Securities and partly paid Securities when determining the number of Equity Securities for the “Relevant Issues” subtraction, and how does that counting interact with the requirement for approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the formula (20% × Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues unless it has approval from the holders of Ordinary Securities. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] To apply that formula correctly, the entity must calculate the number of Equity Securities it is issuing or agreeing to issue (including those that contribute to “Relevant Issues”) using the specified counting rules, unless the Regulator determines otherwise. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] In that calculation, each partly paid Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be paid up, and each Convertible Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be converted. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Those counted amounts then feed into the “Relevant Issues” figure, which is defined as Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, excluding those done with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5 or under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Accordingly, the counting method determines the size of the subtraction for Relevant Issues and, in turn, whether the proposed issue exceeds the cap and therefore requires holder approval. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: For purposes of the insider dealing restriction, how should a compliance function determine whether an investment is a “Related Instrument” to a Financial Instrument, and what is the resulting scope of the prohibition on an Insider dealing or attempting to deal when the Inside Information relates to the underlying Financial Instrument?
gold_answer: An investment is treated as a “Related Instrument” where, in relation to a Financial Instrument, its price or value depends on the price or value of that Financial Instrument; this dependency test is the defining criterion for bringing the investment within the Related Instrument category [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f]. Once an investment meets that definition, the insider dealing restriction applies not only to the Financial Instrument to which the Inside Information relates, but also to the Related Instrument, meaning an Insider is prohibited from dealing or attempting to deal in relation to either the relevant Financial Instrument (and, where applicable, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity to which the Inside Information relates) or the Related Instrument [#SRC:4d6d9fa5-5edd-4280-9d7b-90fca017f5d7]. Practically, if an Insider has Inside Information about an Issuer of Financial Instruments, the prohibition can extend to a Derivative linked to those Financial Instruments, or to another Financial Instrument in a member of the Issuer’s Group, provided the price or value of that other instrument depends (in whole or in part) on the price or value of the Issuer’s Financial Instruments [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f].
source_text: Related Instruments. Section 92(2) prohibits an Insider from dealing or attempting to deal in relation to either the Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity (i.e. to which the Inside Information relates) or a Related Instrument.  The definition of a "Related Instrument" is set out at paragraph 1(9) of the CMC.
target_text:
Application to Financial Instruments and Related Instruments. Section 92(2) (Insider Dealing) also applies to a "Related Instrument", which is defined as meaning:
"…in relation to a Financial Instrument, an investment whose price or value depends on the price or value of the Financial Instrument."
For example, if an Insider has Inside Information relating to an Issuer, A, of Financial Instruments, then a "Related Instrument" could include a Derivative relating to the Financial Instruments of A or another Financial Instrument in a member of A's Group, if the price or value of that other Financial Instrument depends, in whole or in part, on the price or value of Financial Instruments of A.

question: What does an Authorised Person have to do to keep its group capital position compliant at all times, and if it falls short, how will the Regulator look at the situation (including any fixes made by the Authorised Person or another regulator) before deciding on enforcement?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to keep its Financial Group Capital Resources at least equal to, or higher than, its Financial Group Capital Requirement at all times, based on the specified methods for calculating each figure [#TGT:b0fe779d-b7f0-48a6-a00d-06a3f3dc8106]. This is a continuous obligation, so the Authorised Person should be able to demonstrate that it monitors and manages its capital position so that resources do not drop below the requirement. If the Authorised Person breaches the relevant rule connected to this requirement, the Regulator will not decide enforcement solely on the fact of the breach; it will take into account the full circumstances of the case when determining what enforcement action, if any, it will take [#SRC:12a7fe75-3ede-4f19-86af-34a1e60cfe3b]. In doing so, the Regulator will consider remedial steps, including steps taken by the Authorised Person itself and steps taken by another regulator. Practically, that means the Authorised Person’s corrective actions and any parallel regulatory remediation can be important context in how the Regulator assesses the breach and whether enforcement is warranted.
source_text: If an Authorised Person breaches Rule 8.3.2, the Regulator will take into account the full circumstances of the case, including any remedial steps taken by another regulator or the Authorised Person, in determining what enforcement action, if any, it will take.
target_text: An Authorised Person must ensure at all times that its Financial Group Capital Resources, as calculated in Rule 8.3.4, are equal to or in excess of its Financial Group Capital Requirement as calculated in Rule 8.3.3.

question: If someone is listed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and an investor buys the Securities and loses money because the Prospectus had an untrue or misleading statement or left out a required material matter, what can that liable person prove or do to avoid civil liability—especially what must happen before the investor acquires the Securities relying on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: If a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, they can be required to pay compensation to a person who acquired the Securities covered by that Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because of an untrue or misleading statement or because a required material matter was omitted. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] Even in that setting, the person can avoid incurring civil liability if they can demonstrate one of the defenses that focus on truthfulness, reasonable investigation, or prompt correction before acquisition. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554] In practice, the liable person must be able to show at least one of these: the statement was actually true (and not false, misleading, or deceptive), or the omitted matter that caused the loss was properly left out; they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed the Prospectus contained no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission; or, crucially, before the Securities were acquired by anyone relying on the Prospectus, they took all steps that were reasonable for them to take to get a correction made promptly and to bring that correction to the attention of people likely to acquire the Securities. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554]
source_text:
A Person does not incur civil liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if that Person can show that:
(a)	the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive or that the matter the omission of which caused the loss was properly omitted;
(b)	he made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed that there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or
(c)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person in reliance on the Prospectus, he had taken all such steps as were reasonable for him to have taken to secure that a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of the Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: During a period of financial or liquidity stress, if an Authorised Person liquidates part of its stock of HQLA to generate cash for outflows and, as a result, its HQLA level falls below what is required for its LCR Requirement, what notification must it make to the Regulator and when must that notification be made?
gold_answer: During a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person is permitted to liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows, and its level of HQLA may fall below the levels required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with those outflows [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f]. However, if the Authorised Person does not meet its LCR Requirement as a consequence of that liquidation and resulting reduction in HQLA, or if it becomes aware of circumstances arising from the stress and outflows that may result in it not meeting its LCR Requirement, it must notify the Regulator in writing immediately [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c]. This obligation applies at any time, and expressly includes periods of stress, so the permissibility of drawing down HQLA to manage outflows does not remove the requirement to provide immediate written notice when the LCR Requirement is not met or is at risk of not being met [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f] [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c].
source_text: Liquidation of assets during periods of stress . During a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person may liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows. Subject to Rule 9.3.9, the Authorised Person's level of HQLA may fall below the levels required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with cash outflows during that period.
target_text: Notification if LCR Requirement is not met . An Authorised Person must notify the Regulator in writing immediately if it does not meet, or becomes aware of circumstances that may result in it not meeting, at any time, its LCR Requirement (including during a period of stress referred to in Rule 9.3.8).

question: If a Relevant Person wants to use another firm to do parts of CDD, when can it do that, and what must it consider to decide whether the other country’s AML/TFS rules are equivalent to FATF standards?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person can rely on another firm for parts of CDD only if several conditions are met and it has made an equivalence judgement about the other country’s AML/TFS regime. The permission to rely applies only where the Relevant Person immediately gets the necessary CDD information from the third party, takes adequate steps to be satisfied that certified copies of the documents used for the CDD work will be available on request without delay, confirms the third party has not used an exception from doing the CDD elements the Relevant Person wants to rely on, and ensures the information is up to date where applicable [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275]. A key condition is that the third party is regulated (including AML/TFS compliance requirements) by a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator or other competent authority in a country with AML/TFS regulations equivalent to FATF standards and is supervised for compliance. In making that equivalence assessment, the Relevant Person must take into account factors such as FATF/IMF/World Bank/OECD or other international reports, relevant memberships, contextual factors like political stability and corruption, recent criticism (including advisory notices and public assessments), and whether there are adequate co-operation arrangements between the foreign AML/TFS regulator and the Regulator [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4].

question: When an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM applies to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM, what fee basis applies to the application, and in what circumstance may the Regulator additionally impose a supplementary fee linked to the destination jurisdiction’s regulatory cooperation arrangements?
gold_answer: For an application by an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM to establish a branch outside ADGM, the applicant must pay an application fee calculated as 50% of the highest application fee in Chapter 3 for the Regulated Activities it proposes to carry on from that branch. [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] In addition to that application-fee basis, the Regulator may also charge a supplementary fee where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction in which there is not an adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator for that jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] Practically, this means the fee outcome has two components: (i) a mandatory application fee tied to the highest Chapter 3 fee applicable to the Regulated Activities intended to be undertaken from the branch, and (ii) a potential extra charge that depends on whether the destination jurisdiction has adequate regulatory cooperation arrangements in place with the Regulator. [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] The supplementary fee is not automatic; it is triggered by the absence of an adequate memorandum of understanding with the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in the jurisdiction where the branch would operate.
