[#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]
source_text: The Regulator may charge a supplementary fee in addition to the fees specified in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2 where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding in place between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction.
target_text: Where an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM applies to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM, it must pay to the Regulator an application fee equal to 50% of the highest application fee set out in Chapter 3 of these Rules for those Regulated Activities it seeks to undertake from the proposed branch.

question: When an Authorised Person prepares or publishes Investment Research while providing any Regulated Activities, what conflict-of-interest identification steps must it take under Principle 7 (Rule 2.2.7), and which categories of relationships must be considered in addition to maintaining adequate procedures and controls for the research output?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person preparing or publishing Investment Research must both maintain adequate procedures and controls for that research and take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest, with the identification exercise aligned to Principle 7 as outlined in Rule 2.2.7. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] In practice, the conflict-identification duty applies to conflicts that arise or may arise in the course of the Authorised Person providing any Regulated Activities, so the Authorised Person should assess conflicts connected to those activities even where the immediate deliverable is Investment Research. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] The categories that must be considered when identifying conflicts include: (i) conflicts between the Authorised Person (including its managers, Employees and Clients, and any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control) and a Client; and (ii) conflicts between one Client and another Client. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] Separately, beyond identification, the Authorised Person is required to prevent or manage conflicts once identified, and this sits alongside the requirement to have adequate procedures and controls for Investment Research preparation or publication. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]
source_text: The requirements in this Rule ‎6.4.2 apply to an Authorised Person in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder. For example, an Authorised Person is required to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them under GEN 3.3.21-3.3.24. An Authorised Person must also have adequate procedures and controls when it prepares or publishes Investment Research.
target_text:
Conflicts of Interest: An Authorised Person must comply with Principle 7 as outlined in Rule ‎2.2.7, taking all reasonable steps to identify conflicts of interest between:
(1)	the Authorised Person, including its managers, Employees and Clients, or any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control; or
(2)	one Client of the Authorised Person and another Client,
that arises or may arise in the course of the Authorised Person providing any Regulated Activities.

question: When is a Prospectus treated as an Approved Prospectus, and why is filing it with the Regulator not enough unless the Regulator sends the Applicant an approval notice (including for a Prospectus made up of several documents)?
gold_answer: A Prospectus is treated as an Approved Prospectus only when it has actually been approved by the Regulator in line with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and the Regulations generally treat any reference to a “Prospectus” as meaning an Approved Prospectus unless the context requires otherwise [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1]. The Source adds an important practical condition: simply filing a Prospectus with the Regulator does not make it an Approved Prospectus unless the Regulator has issued a notice to the Applicant stating that it approves the Prospectus (or, where relevant, the Supplementary Prospectus) [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. If the Prospectus is made up of multiple documents, the approval notice must state approval of all of those documents, not just some of them [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. Put together, the Target provides the definition based on Regulator approval under the Rules, while the Source explains that the approval must be evidenced by a specific notice issued to the Applicant, and that the notice must cover the full set of documents where the Prospectus is multi-part.
source_text:
A Prospectus filed with the Regulator is not an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2)(a) of the FSMR unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval:
(a)	of the Prospectus or the Supplementary Prospectus as the case may be; and
(b)	in the case of a Prospectus in (a) comprising multiple documents, of all the multiple documents.
target_text:
For the purposes of subsection ‎(1)—
(a)	a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules; and
(b)	a reference to a Prospectus made by or under these Regulations is a reference to an Approved Prospectus, unless the context requires otherwise.

question: In what circumstances is the Regulator permitted to refuse to grant an application for registration, and how does that permission apply both to a Fund generally and specifically to a Public Fund?
gold_answer: Across both passages, the Regulator is permitted to refuse to grant an application for registration when a specific condition is not met: the Regulator is not satisfied that the relevant requirements have been met. In the SOURCE, this permission applies to an application for the registration of a Fund, and the refusal power is triggered if the Regulator is not satisfied that the requirements referred to in the referenced requirements provision have been met [#SRC:4881ebd8-8cd6-4bd0-b0fe-19b9b9a421bf]. In the TARGET, the same refusal permission is stated in the context of an Application for registration of a Public Fund, again conditioned on the Regulator not being satisfied that the requirements referred to in the same referenced requirements provision have been met [#TGT:84155043-3488-4333-94e3-f4dae46b6df3]. Read together, the common compliance implication is that an Applicant should expect the Regulator to assess whether the applicable requirements have been met before granting registration, and that a failure to satisfy the Regulator on those requirements can result in rejection of the application, whether the application concerns a Fund generally or a Public Fund specifically.
source_text: Under Section 109 of the FSMR, the Regulator may refuse to grant an application for the registration of a Fund if it is not satisfied that the requirements referred to in Section 107 of the FSMR have been met.
target_text:
Rejection of an Application
The Regulator may refuse to grant an Application for registration of a Public Fund if it is not satisfied that the requirements referred to in section ‎107 have been met.

question: If a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, how does it have to send the refusal notice, and where should the agreed way of sending notices be written down for the Customer?
gold_answer: When a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, it must send a notification of that refusal, and it must send it using the agreed manner for providing the notification [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. The place where that “agreed manner” should be clearly set out for the Customer is the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers, unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer otherwise agree in writing [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. The Governing Contract must include the means of communication agreed between the parties for transmitting information or notifications, and it must also cover any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software to receive those notifications [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. This ensures the Customer knows exactly how refusal notifications will be delivered (for example, via the agreed communication channel) and what is needed to receive them, so the Third Party Provider can meet its obligation to notify in the agreed manner when a refusal occurs [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].
source_text: Refusal of Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide the notification in the agreed manner of the refusal as set out in Rule 20.2.2.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target and, in the same disclosure package, also discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, what specific categories of assumptions and supporting information must be included for (i) the forecast financial information and (ii) the Ore Reserves estimate, including how commercially sensitive material economic assumptions are to be handled?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure the disclosure covers two distinct but complementary information sets: the assumption framework supporting the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, and the key technical context required when an Ore Reserves estimate is disclosed. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129] For the forecast financial information, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used, plus all other material assumptions applied. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions (rather than omitting the topic entirely). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The disclosure must also identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and include the information required to be contained in that Production Target disclosure. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Separately, when disclosing an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure must also include key information on mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status, and the relative accuracy/confidence. [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Rule 11.6 also requires that when a Mining Reporting Entity discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure is also to include key information relating to mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status and the relative accuracy/confidence.

question: If a Reporting Entity asks the Listing Authority for a Trading Halt or Suspension because it needs time to get a Disclosure of Inside Information ready, what details does it usually have to explain, and what situations (like lost confidentiality or the RIE being open/closed) can make a Trading Halt or Suspension necessary?
gold_answer: When a Reporting Entity asks the Listing Authority for a Trading Halt or Suspension to create time to prepare and release a Disclosure of Inside Information, the Listing Authority typically requires a clear explanation of the request and then makes its own judgment on whether the halt/suspension is warranted. [#SRC:22a51628-c5c0-43b8-b062-2c8145b3a2c6] The Reporting Entity will usually be asked to describe: what the Inside Information is about, why it needs the Trading Halt or Suspension, what event is expected to end the halt/suspension, and what it plans to disclose (scope) and when it expects to release that Disclosure. [#SRC:22a51628-c5c0-43b8-b062-2c8145b3a2c6] A Trading Halt or Suspension may be necessary to manage Disclosure issues in several situations, including where there are signs the Inside Information is no longer confidential before Disclosure and it is affecting price (or, if the RIE is not yet open, is likely to affect price when the RIE opens). [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9] It can also be necessary if the Listing Authority has asked the Reporting Entity to correct or prevent a false market, or if the Inside Information is especially significant and likely to cause a major price movement (for example, a significant capital raising, the Board resolving to appoint an administrator, or approval of a one-off contract that substantially changes the Listed Entity’s scale and activities). [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9] The RIE’s trading status is part of the necessity analysis: if trading is open and the Reporting Entity cannot disclose immediately, or if trading is closed and it cannot disclose before the RIE opens, that supports using a Trading Halt or Suspension. [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9]
target_text:
IMMEDIATELY
Use of a Trading Halt or Suspension to manage Disclosure issues
A Trading Halt or Suspension may, however, be necessary in the following circumstances:

a)	there are indications that the Inside Information has lost its confidentiality ahead of a Disclosure (see Rule 7.2.2(2)), and it is having, or (where the RIE upon which the Listed Entity’s Securities are admitted to trading is not yet open for trading) is likely to have, when the RIE opens for trading, a significant effect on the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities;

b)	the Reporting Entity has been asked by the Listing Authority to correct or prevent a false market;  or

c)	the information is particularly significant Inside Information and likely to cause a significant movement in the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities (for example, Inside Information relating to a significant capital raising, the Board of the Listed Entity resolving to appoint an administrator, or that the Listed Entity is to win approval for a one-off contract that will substantially change the scale and activities of the Listed Entity);

and in circumstances where the RIE’s market is:

d)	open for trading in the Listed Entity’s Securities, the Reporting Entity is not in a position to make the Disclosure immediately; or

e)	not open for trading in the Listed Entity’s Securities, the Reporting Entity will not be in a position to make the Disclosure before the RIE opens for trading.

question: For an Issuer conducting an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), how should the Issuer reconcile the requirement that the Product Summary Note carry a prominent front-page disclaimer with the general prohibition on including disclaimers in relation to information disclosed in, or in respect of, the Product Summary Note?
gold_answer: In an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), the Issuer is required to include a specific prominent disclaimer on the front of the Product Summary Note, in bold, using the disclaimer referenced in Rule 4.3.4. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] At the same time, Issuers are generally required to refrain from including disclaimers relating to information disclosed in the Product Summary Note or disclaimers made in respect of the Product Summary Note. [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04] Read together, the Issuer should treat the front-page disclaimer mandated for the Exempt Offer Product Summary Note as the only disclaimer content that is affirmatively required, and avoid adding any other disclaimer language that would operate as a disclaimer “in relation to” the information in the Product Summary Note or “in respect of” the Product Summary Note. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04] This approach aligns with the Product Summary Note content controls that it must be fair and balanced, not false or misleading, and must not omit information in a way that makes any part false or misleading, which would be undermined by additional disclaimer-style qualifications. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2]
source_text: Subject to Rule 4.3.5, Issuers shall refrain from including disclaimers in relation to information disclosed in the Product Summary Note or in respect of the Product Summary Note.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count the risk-reduction effect of CRM using Collateral (the types mentioned in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7), what must it check and set up first under the “Requirements for Recognition of Collateral,” especially about being able to sell/take the Collateral quickly and what happens when a custodian holds it?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person can only recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral referred to in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7 if it ensures the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are met, because those requirements are the gateway conditions for recognition. [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] Practically, before recognising CRM, it must confirm that the legal method used to pledge, assign, or transfer the Collateral gives it a right to liquidate or take legal possession in a timely way if the Counterparty defaults or becomes insolvent/bankrupt (or if other defined credit events in the transaction documents occur), and this also extends to the custodian’s default/insolvency/bankruptcy where applicable. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] It must also have taken all steps needed under the law governing its interest in the Collateral to obtain and keep an enforceable security interest (including registration where required) or to exercise net/set-off rights for title transfer Collateral. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] In addition, it must have procedures that allow prompt liquidation while observing any legal conditions for declaring the Counterparty in default, and if a custodian holds the Collateral, it must take reasonable steps to ensure the custodian keeps the Collateral separate from the custodian’s own assets. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]
source_text:
Collateral
In order to recognise the effects of CRM of the types of Collateral set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person must ensure that the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with.

question: When changing a Trustee, what must the Fund Manager check to avoid a non-independent Trustee relationship, and what are the two ways (certification or Unitholder vote) to support the Regulator’s approval?
gold_answer: Before proposing a replacement, the Fund Manager must check that the incoming Trustee will be independent of the Fund Manager for that Investment Trust. The Trustee will not be independent if there are cross-holdings of Shares or voting rights, a common holding company or common ultimate holding company, overlapping Directors on each other’s Governing Bodies, shared individuals performing Controlled Functions, or professional/material business dealings in the last two years other than acting as Fund Manager or Trustee respectively [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]. To obtain the Regulator’s approval to replace the Trustee, the Fund Manager must give the Regulator a written notice of its intention to remove the Trustee and then follow one of two routes: provide a certification that the change will not adversely affect Unitholders’ interests and the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with its obligations, or provide a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. In all cases, the Regulator must also receive the written consent of the proposed replacement Trustee, and the proposed replacement must meet the applicable requirements to be able to act as replacement Trustee [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2].
source_text:
The Regulator may grant approval for the replacement of a Trustee only where it has received:
(a)	a written notice from the Fund Manager of its intention to remove the Trustee and either:
(i)	a certification that the removal of the Trustee will not adversely affect the interests of the Unitholders and the Fund Manager's ability to comply with its obligations under the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR; or
(ii)	a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the Fund Manager's proposal to remove the Trustee and its replacement with another Trustee; and
(b)	the written consent of the person who agrees to be the replacement Trustee, and that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act as the replacement Trustee.

question: If an Authorised Person is using the FCCA and has eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, what must it calculate for the exposure and what inputs (including haircuts and currency mismatch) must it use, and how is that result then used in the credit risk weighted exposure amount?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person using the FCCA that has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement must calculate an adjusted exposure amount called E* under the applicable Rules, and then substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the relevant CR Exposure [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de]. For collateralised transactions in scope of the haircut method—meaning the transaction is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement or a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, and it is not an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction—the Authorised Person must calculate E* using the stated formula under the FCCA with standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949]. To do this, it must identify E as the fair value of the Exposure, apply the Exposure haircut (HE), identify C as the fair value of eligible financial Collateral received, apply the Collateral haircut (HC) (or a weighted sum if the Collateral is a basket), and apply the currency mismatch haircut (HFX) where relevant. The formula also requires that E* cannot be negative (it is floored at zero).
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.

question: If an Authorised Person is using the FCCA, what kinds of assets count as eligible financial Collateral, and what extra step must the Authorised Person take before they can recognise the effects of CRM for that Collateral?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral is limited to specific categories, and recognising the effects of CRM for those Collateral types requires meeting an additional compliance condition. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] The eligible categories are: any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5; any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and Units in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities, but only where the Unit price is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] Separately, to recognise the effects of CRM for Collateral types covered by Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, the Authorised Person must ensure the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with. [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] Putting these together, even if an asset fits one of the FCCA eligible Collateral categories (including the Fund Unit category with its daily pricing and 90% investment threshold), the Authorised Person still needs to satisfy Rule 4.13.8 before CRM recognition is available for the relevant Collateral type. [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]
source_text:
Collateral
In order to recognise the effects of CRM of the types of Collateral set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person must ensure that the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If an Authorised Person runs a Recognised Investment Exchange, Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility for Accepted Spot Commodities, which MIR Chapter 5 rules do they have to follow in the listed Item situations, and how do the MIR words “Recognised Body” and “Financial Instrument” get read for Rule 22.7.4?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person in this position must comply with the MIR, Chapter 5 requirements that are specifically called out: Rules 5.1–5.3 and Rule 5.4.1, and this duty applies only in the circumstances identified in the enumerated Items (including Items 19, 20, 24(a) and (b), 27, 28, 32, 33, 35, 37, 38, 39, 41, 43, 45, 46, 47, 48, 49, 50, 52, 53, 54, 55, 57, 58, 59, 60, 61 and 62). [#TGT:3fec174f-e21d-4aa0-b244-0034deb32874] When interpreting MIR for the purposes of Rule 22.7.4 in this Accepted Spot Commodities context, you must also apply the required term substitutions: wherever MIR uses “Recognised Body” or “Recognised Bodies,” it is to be understood as “Authorised Person.” [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3] Similarly, wherever MIR uses “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments,” it is to be understood as “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities,” as appropriate. [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3] Putting these together, the Authorised Person applies the specified Chapter 5 rules in the listed Item situations, while reading those two MIR terms through the Rule 22.7.4 substitutions. [#TGT:3fec174f-e21d-4aa0-b244-0034deb32874] [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3]
source_text:
For the purposes of Rule 22.7.4, all references in MIR to -
(a)	“Recognised Body” or “Recognised Bodies” shall be read as references to “Authorised Person”; and
(b)	“Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” shall be read as references to “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities”, as applicable.
target_text:
An Authorised Person that is Operating a Recognised Investment Exchange, Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities must comply with the following requirements set out in MIR, Chapter 5 -
(a)	Rules 5.1 - 5.3; and
(b)	Rule 5.4.1, in the circumstances identified in Items 19, 20, 24 (a) and (b), 27, 28, 32, 33, 35, 37, 38, 39, 41, 43, 45, 46, 47, 48, 49, 50, 52, 53, 54, 55, 57, 58, 59, 60, 61 and 62.

question: If an ADGM Branch is failing (or likely to fail) and the Non-ADGM Institution is under a Foreign Resolution Action, when is the Regulator allowed to take Resolution Action for the ADGM Branch, and when could the Regulator refuse to recognise that Foreign Resolution Action in a way that matters to this decision?
gold_answer: The Regulator may take a Resolution Action in respect of an ADGM Branch only if it is satisfied that several conditions are met: the ADGM Branch is failing or likely to fail; given the timing and other relevant circumstances, it is not reasonably likely that any action by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or the Non-ADGM Institution will prevent that failure; using a Resolution Tool is in the public interest; and the Non-ADGM Institution is either not subject (and not likely soon to be subject) to any Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings, or it is subject to Foreign Resolution Action and a specified circumstance applies in respect of the Non-ADGM Institution [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726]. Separately, even where there is a Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may refuse to recognise it (in whole or in part) if it is satisfied that one or more listed concerns apply—such as harm to financial stability in the ADGM, Resolution Conditions not being met, ADGM Branch action not being necessary to achieve Resolution Objectives, worse treatment of ADGM creditors compared with creditors in the non-ADGM jurisdiction, or material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba].
source_text:
A Resolution Action may be taken in respect of an ADGM Branch only if the Regulator is satisfied that the following conditions are met—
(a)	the ADGM Branch is failing or is likely to fail;
(b)	having regard to timing and other relevant circumstances, it is not reasonably likely that any action will be taken by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution that will prevent the failure or likely failure of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution;
(c)	the application of a Resolution Tool is in the public interest; and
(d)	the Non-ADGM Institution is—
(i)	not subject to, and not likely in a reasonable timeframe to be subject to, any Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings; or
(ii)	subject to Foreign Resolution Action, and one of the circumstances referred to in section 78(2) applies in respect of the Non-ADGM Institution.

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business plans to deposit Client Money into a Client Account established with a Third-Party Agent, what specific written acknowledgment must it obtain from the Third-Party Agent, and how should that acknowledgment be treated within the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack record set?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must obtain a written acknowledgment from the Third-Party Agent before it deposits Client Money into a Client Account established with that Third-Party Agent. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] That acknowledgment must state (i) that all Money standing to the credit of the account is held by the Authorised Person on behalf of its Clients, and (ii) that the Third-Party Agent has no entitlement to combine the account with any other account or to assert any charge, mortgage, security, lien, right of set-off, combination, or counterclaim against Money in the account for amounts owed to it by the Authorised Person. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] From a records and resolution-planning perspective, the Authorised Person must ensure that records relating to Third-Party Agent acknowledgment in respect of Client Money are included in its Resolution Pack. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In practice, this means the written acknowledgment obtained as a precondition to depositing Client Money should be retained and organized as part of the Resolution Pack materials covering Third-Party Agent acknowledgment for Client Money, alongside the other specified Resolution Pack records (such as master lists of Client Accounts and the most recent reconciliations). [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]
target_text: Before depositing Client Money in a Client Account established with a Third-Party Agent, it must obtain a written acknowledgment from the Third-Party Agent stating that all Money standing to the credit of the account is held by the Authorised Person on behalf of its Clients and that the Third-Party Agent is not entitled to combine the account with any other account, or exercise any charge, mortgage, security, lien, right of set-off or combination or counterclaim against Money in that account in respect of any sum owed to it by the Authorised Person.

question: For an Authorised Person measuring E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, how is E determined for (i) lending or selling Securities with a commitment to repurchase and (ii) lending or paying cash with a commitment to resell, and in what circumstances may the Authorised Person recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral when the exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15?
gold_answer: E must be measured using the specified transaction-type amounts when the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arises from an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, and eligible financial Collateral may only be recognised where the SFT exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15 and the collateral is eligible financial Collateral taken for that SFT. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Where the Authorised Person has lent Securities to a Counterparty or sold Securities to a Counterparty with a commitment to repurchase those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, E is the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] Where the Authorised Person has lent cash to a Counterparty through borrowing Securities from the Counterparty, or has paid cash to purchase Securities from a Counterparty with a commitment to resell those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, E is the amount of cash lent or paid. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] Separately, if the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15, the Authorised Person may recognise the effect of that collateral, but only in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text:
Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must determine E, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT which is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement as follows:
(a)	in the case where the Authorised Person has lent Securities to a Counterparty or sold Securities to a Counterparty with a commitment to repurchase those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold; and
(b)	in the case where the Authorised Person has lent cash to a Counterparty through the borrowing of Securities from the Counterparty or paid cash for the purchase of Securities from a Counterparty with a commitment to resell those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the amount of cash lent or paid.

question: Where a Payment Service Provider offers a Single Payment Service Contract that is also intended to sit within a Framework Contract, what pre-contract information must be provided to the Payment Service User before they are bound, and how should that be aligned with the Framework Contract’s required disclosures on execution timing, identifiers, and charges (including exchange-rate details where relevant)?
gold_answer: The Payment Service Provider must ensure the Payment Service User receives specified pre-contract information for the Single Payment Service Contract before the Payment Service User becomes bound, and that this pre-contract package is consistent with the corresponding Framework Contract disclosures on the same topics. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] Before the Payment Service User is bound, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available (for example via a draft Single Payment Service Contract or draft Payment Order) the identifier or other information the Payment Service User must supply for proper initiation/execution, the maximum execution time, the charges (and breakdown where applicable), and—where applicable—the actual or Reference Exchange Rate to be applied. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] In parallel, the Framework Contract must include, among other items, the identifier information for initiating/executing Payment Orders, the maximum execution time for the Payment Services, and detailed charges payable (including charges connected to information being provided/made available and a breakdown where applicable). [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] Where exchange rates are relevant, the Framework Contract must also include the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are used, the method for calculating the relevant date for determining them. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: If an Authorised Person runs Regulated Activities from a branch outside ADGM, what fee do they pay each year and how is the first payment handled, and when could the Regulator add a supplementary fee because of the branch’s country?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has established a branch outside ADGM and uses that branch to conduct Regulated Activities, it must pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee set at 50% of the highest annual supervision fee for the Regulated Activities it carries on from that branch. [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] The first supervision fee payment is not automatically the full annual amount; instead, the initial supervision fee must be prorated and paid in the manner described in Rule 1.2.2(a). [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] Separately, the Regulator may also charge a supplementary fee (on top of the fees referenced in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2) when the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] In practical terms, the supervision fee is driven by the branch’s Regulated Activities and the proration rule for the initial payment, while the supplementary fee is tied to whether the branch’s jurisdiction has adequate regulator-to-regulator cooperation arrangements in place. [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]
source_text: The Regulator may charge a supplementary fee in addition to the fees specified in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2 where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding in place between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction.
target_text: An Authorised Person that has established a branch outside ADGM from which it conducts Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator an annual supervision fee equal to 50% of the highest annual supervision fee for those Regulated Activities it undertakes from the branch.  The initial supervision fee due shall be prorated and paid in accordance with Rule 1.2.2(a).

question: When an Authorised Person is designing and operating anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems, how must it meet its duty to establish and maintain effective systems and controls to deter, prevent, and report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes, and to what extent may it incorporate secure authentication, biometrics, and monitoring of customer behaviour metrics as part of those systems and controls?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must establish and maintain effective systems and controls that are capable of deterring and preventing suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers, and it must also ensure those systems and controls support reporting suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596]. In meeting that obligation, the Authorised Person should observe best practices when establishing the required systems and controls, recognising that Financial Crime evolves over time [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]. Those best practices may include incorporating secure authentication, biometrics, and the monitoring of customer behaviour metrics into the anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls, as part of a broader control framework aimed at deterrence, prevention, and effective escalation/reporting of suspected activity [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]. Accordingly, the obligation sets the required outcomes (effective deterrence, prevention, and reporting), while the permission/guidance supports using these specific techniques as optional components to strengthen the overall effectiveness of the systems and controls [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7].
source_text: An Authorised Person should observe best practices when establishing the systems and controls required under Rule 3.3.38, given the evolving nature of Financial Crime. Such practices may include, but are not limited to, incorporating secure authentication, biometrics and the monitoring of customer behaviour metrics into anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls.
target_text:
Fraud and other Financial Crimes: An Authorised Person must establish and maintain effective systems and controls to:
(1)	deter and prevent suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers; and
(2)	report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities.

question: When the Regulator is considering whether it may decline to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (in whole or in part) due to one of the specified adverse-impact or fairness conditions, how does that decision constrain the Regulator’s ability to deploy Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers to support or give full effect to the action, including any need for ex-ante judicial approval?
gold_answer: The Regulator’s ability to use Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers to support, or give full effect to, a foreign measure depends on the measure being a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action. The SOURCE establishes that the Regulator may refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action in whole or in part where it is satisfied that one or more listed conditions apply, including adverse effects on financial stability in the ADGM, failure to meet the Resolution Conditions for the relevant entity, lack of necessity for Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch to achieve Resolution Objectives, unequal treatment or legal rights for ADGM-located or payable creditors compared with those in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction, or material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]. The TARGET then permits the Regulator to exercise one or more Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers only for the purpose of supporting, or giving full effect to, a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action, and makes that permission subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval [#TGT:5798f720-7021-4b63-9ebe-f1a30aebee29]. Accordingly, if recognition is refused (or refused in part), the Regulator’s supporting actions are correspondingly limited to what is recognised, and any exercise of tools or powers remains conditioned by applicable ex-ante judicial approval requirements.
target_text: For the purposes of supporting, or giving full effect to, a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may exercise one or more Resolution Tools, or one or more Resolution Powers, subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval in compliance with section 27.

question: What kinds of problems could lead FSRA to cancel an FSP without waiting for a FinTech Participant’s request, and how is that kind of action described in the context of variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission?
gold_answer: FSRA can cancel an FSP on the initiative of the Regulator where it appears to the Regulator that specific problems exist, rather than relying only on a FinTech Participant’s application. The SOURCE lists three main categories: (1) the FinTech Participant is failing, or is likely to fail, to satisfy the Threshold Conditions; (2) it is desirable to exercise the power to further one or more of the Regulators objectives, including where the FinTech Participant is failing, or likely to fail, to satisfy authorisation requirements or to satisfy limitations or conditions; and (3) the FinTech Participant has committed a contravention of the FSMR or any Rules made under the FSMR [#SRC:a196fe29-bdce-4820-ad63-7fbde525c991]. The TARGET describes this type of step at a higher level by grouping it under “Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission” and explicitly referencing “Variation or cancellation on initiative of the Regulator,” which matches the SOURCE’s concept of Regulator-initiated cancellation [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a]. Read together, they show that FSRA’s own-initiative cancellation is a recognised part of the permission management toolkit, triggered by likely non-compliance, objective-driven necessity, or contraventions.
source_text:
Cancellation of the FSP. FSRA may cancel the FSP on the application of the FinTech Participant, in accordance with section 32 of the FSMR, or on the initiative of the Regulator, in accordance with section 33 of the FSMR, if it appears to the Regulator that:
(a)	the FinTech Participant is failing, or is likely to fail, to satisfy the Threshold Conditions made under section 7(2) of the FSMR and set out in paragraph 5.2(a) of this Guidance;
(b)	it is desirable to exercise this power to further one or more of the Regulator’s objectives, including, for example, if:
i.	the FinTech Participant is failing, or is likely to fail, to satisfy the authorisation requirements set out in section 5.2(b) – (f) of this Guidance; or
ii.	the FinTech Participant is failing, or is likely to fail, to satisfy the limitations or conditions set out in section 7.1 of this Guidance; or
(c)	the FinTech Participant has committed a contravention of the FSMR or any Rules made under the FSMR.
target_text: Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission. Variation or cancellation on initiative of the Regulator

question: If a Relevant Person is about to hire a service provider to do CDD and that work will use an eKYC System, what should the Relevant Person check in the initial assurance assessment, and what must be written down before the hire happens?
gold_answer: Before hiring the service provider, the Relevant Person must carry out an initial assurance assessment to judge whether the service provider is suitable to undertake CDD, and the Relevant Person must have the service provider’s obligations clearly set out in a binding agreement before the appointment is made. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752] Where the arrangement involves an eKYC System and the assurance work is being undertaken for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A, the Relevant Person should use the assessment to establish that the eKYC System is reliable and independent and that it allows the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] To strengthen how the assessment is performed, the Relevant Person should also consider applying assurance standards guidance from the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard-setting bodies. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] Taken together, the pre-appointment steps are: assess suitability of the service provider for CDD, test the eKYC System against reliability/independence and compliance enablement expectations, and document the service provider’s obligations in a binding agreement before appointment. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752] [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4]
source_text: When undertaking an assurance assessment of an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule ‎9.3.1A, a Relevant Person should seek to establish that the eKYC System is reliable and independent, and allows the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator. In addition, a Relevant Person should consider applying guidance on assurance standards issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard setting bodies.
target_text: Prior to appointing a service provider to undertake CDD, a Relevant Person must undertake an initial assurance assessment to evaluate the suitability of the service provider and must ensure that the service provider's obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement.

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 12.6.1 that includes new, previously undisclosed material estimates of Contingent Resources, what specific content must be included to address both (i) the Rule 12.6.1 “new data/information” impact explanation and (ii) the additional Contingent Resources disclosure elements (including any technology-under-development or Unconventional Petroleum Resources details, if applicable)?
gold_answer: The Petroleum Reporting Entity must prepare a single disclosure that satisfies both the Rule 12.6.1 “new data/information” update requirements and the specific content required for first-time, material Contingent Resources estimates. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] The disclosure must identify the types of permits or licences held that relate to the estimates (and, for the Contingent Resources component, those relevant to the disclosed Contingent Resources estimates). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] It must explain the new data and information and describe how that new data and information affected the estimates (including Contingent Resources). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] For the previously undisclosed material Contingent Resources, it must also state the basis for confirming a significant quantity of potentially moveable Petroleum and the determination of a discovery, and describe the estimation method, the key contingencies supporting Contingent Resources classification, and any further appraisal drilling/evaluation work to progress the project. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] If the estimates are contingent on technology under development, it must explain the technology’s demonstrated (or not yet demonstrated) commercial viability status and ensure Unrecoverable quantities are not included as Contingent Resources. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] If they relate to Unconventional Petroleum Resources, it must add the specified Unconventional details (type, land area, number of wells, and specialised extraction technology). [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] Finally, it must include any changes or additions to previously disclosed information for Contingent Resources as referenced in Rule 12.10.1(1) to 12.10.1(5). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]

question: In identifying vulnerabilities linked to new or developing technologies, what must a Relevant Person do to ensure its assessment covers eKYC Systems used in NFTF business and reflects any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator or other competent bodies, while also ensuring the resulting risks are mitigated in day-to-day operations?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must identify and assess the money laundering risks to which its business is exposed and, when doing so, must take into account (to the extent relevant) vulnerabilities relating to the use of new or developing technologies for both new and pre-existing products and services [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. Consistent with that requirement, its business risk assessment should include an assessment of the risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems, because those technology-enabled processes can form part of its products, services, activity profiles, and delivery mechanisms [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. The Relevant Person must also take into account that money laundering risks include terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance, so the NFTF/eKYC analysis should be framed within that broader risk set [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. In addition, the assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. Finally, it must take appropriate measures to ensure any identified risk is taken into account in day-to-day operations and is mitigated, including in relation to new products, new customers, and changes to its business profile [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851].
source_text: A business risk assessment under Rule ‎6.1.1(b) should include an assessment of the risks associated with the carrying on of NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems. The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and any other relevant bodies.

question: In meeting its obligations around the Fund Auditor’s Report, how must a Fund Manager structure its written instruction to the auditor regarding the audit, and what minimum content must the Fund Manager ensure the Auditor expressly addresses in the report for the annual accounting period?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager’s obligations operate as a chain from instruction to deliverable. The Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in accordance with the relevant IAASB standards and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on those audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. Beyond requiring the report, the Fund Manager must also manage the report’s substance: in procuring the production of the Fund Auditor’s Report, the Fund Manager must ensure that an Auditor states at least the specified conclusions and disclosures. These include whether the financial statements were properly prepared under the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, whether they present a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and performance for the annual accounting period and at period end, and whether there are issues such as accounting records not being kept, lack of agreement between statements and records/returns, or non-compliance with applicable financial reporting standards [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]. The Auditor must also state whether it received all information and explanations necessary for the audit, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter or opinion required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].
source_text:
Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: What does an Authorised Person’s periodic stress test need to cover for securitisations, if it must also check whether the firm can still do securitisation in the future for CRM or liquidity, and take into account stressed market conditions and pipeline deals that might not close?
gold_answer: The periodic stress test needs to be built so it covers the required securitisation perimeter and also the specific stressed-scenario questions the rules call out. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] First, it must be a periodic stress test that relates to the Authorised Person’s securitisation activities and its off balance sheet Exposures, and it must include testing whether the firm will be able in the future to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] Second, when running those tests, the firm must look at stressed market conditions and assess the firm wide impact of the securitisation activities and Exposures, including what those stresses mean for other sources of risk (not just the securitisation positions themselves). [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] Third, the test scope must include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, because the analysis must reflect the risk that pipeline transactions may not be completed in a stressed market scenario. [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] Putting these together ensures the test covers current and planned securitisation activity, future execution capacity for CRM/liquidity, and the firm-wide consequences under stress. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]
source_text: The periodic stress testing in relation to securitisation activities referred to in Rule 4.14.5 should consider the firm wide impact of those activities and Exposures in stressed market conditions and the implications for other sources of risk. Such stress tests should include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, as there is a risk of the pipeline transactions not being completed in a stressed market scenario.
target_text: Systems and controls for the use of securitisations. An Authorised Person must conduct periodic stress tests in relation to its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, including testing of future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and later makes a subsequent disclosure about those same Non-Equivalent Estimates, how can it both (i) rely on the carve-out from Rule 11.2.1(1) and (ii) avoid repeating the information required by Rule 11.7.3 in the later disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity can avoid complying with Rule 11.2.1(1) for a disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only if it instead complies with the specified alternative set of rules, which includes Rule 11.7.3. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] If the entity has already made a Non-Equivalent Estimates disclosure that complied with Rule 11.7.3, then a later disclosure about those same Non-Equivalent Estimates may omit the information required by Rule 11.7.3, but only if the later disclosure meets all of the conditions tied to that omission. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Practically, to achieve both outcomes, the Mining Reporting Entity should: - Ensure the initial disclosure of the material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation is made in a way that satisfies the alternative compliance pathway (including Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6), so Rule 11.2.1(1) is not required for that disclosure. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] - In the subsequent disclosure, reference the earlier Rule 11.7.3-compliant disclosure and confirm both that the earlier Rule 11.7.3 information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting reliability/interpretation or the entity’s ability to verify the estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] - Include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement addressing the matters covered by Rule 11.7.3(1). [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4]
target_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a Clearing Service from a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, what must it do to make sure clearing and settlement will happen on time, and what must it send to the Regulator?
gold_answer: The Recognised Investment Exchange must do two things that work together. It must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are made to secure the timely discharge—whether by performance, compromise or otherwise—of the clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange, meaning the rights and liabilities that relate to those transactions [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. In addition, if the Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, it must confirm to the Regulator, in writing, the satisfactory arrangements it has made [#SRC:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e]. So, it is not enough to rely on the clearing provider’s processes: the Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure the arrangements exist and are satisfactory for timely clearing and settlement, and it must also provide written confirmation of those arrangements to the Regulator when the provider is outside the specified clearing house categories.
source_text: If a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, the Recognised Investment Exchange must confirm to the Regulator, in writing, the satisfactory arrangements made under Rule 3.8.1.
target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange, when engaging a Clearing Service, must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are made for securing the timely discharge (whether by performance, compromise or otherwise), Clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange (being rights and liabilities in relation to those transactions).

question: If the Third Party Provider confirms a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, when must it refund, and does that timing still apply if it reasonably suspects the Customer is acting fraudulently?
gold_answer: Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide a refund as soon as practicable and no later than the end of the day after the day it made that confirmation [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. But that refund-timing requirement is not universal. The requirement to provide a refund within the prescribed timeframe does not apply where the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]. Putting both points together: the default expectation is a prompt refund after confirmation, with a clear latest deadline, but the Third Party Provider is not required to meet the prescribed refund timeframe if it has reasonable grounds for suspecting Customer fraud. The key practical distinction is that the trigger for the refund deadline is the Third Party Provider’s confirmation about the transaction’s status, while the exception depends on the Third Party Provider having reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer.
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The requirement to provide a refund within the timeframe prescribed in Rule 20.12.2 does not apply where the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer.
target_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, how must it determine the collateralised and uncollateralised portions for CRM recognition, and what minimum or alternative CRW must it apply to the collateralised portion when the CRW derived from treating the Collateral as a direct Exposure would otherwise fall below 20%?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, it is permitted to recognise CRM by splitting the Exposure into a collateralised portion equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral and an uncollateralised portion equal to the CR Exposure amount net of that latest fair value, and then applying the CRW for the collateralised portion as if it had a direct Exposure to the Collateral while applying the obligor’s CRW to the uncollateralised portion [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb]. However, if the CRW that results from that “direct Exposure to the Collateral” approach for the collateralised portion is less than 20%, the Authorised Person must apply a 20% CRW to the collateralised portion, unless one of the specified exceptions applies [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]. Those exceptions allow lower CRWs for certain qualifying SFTs depending on whether the Counterparty is a core market participant, and for certain OTC Derivative transactions subject to daily mark to market with specified collateral types and no currency mismatch, as well as for certain no-currency-mismatch transactions involving cash on Deposit or specified 0% risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures (with a 20% discount condition for the latter).
source_text:
Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows:
(a) 	break down the Exposure into -
(i) 	a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and
(ii) 	an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral;
and
(b) 	for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use:
(i) 	for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and
(ii) 	for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

question: How should an Authorised Person be categorised where its Financial Services Permission includes Managing Assets and it also undertakes Dealing in Investments as Agent, but only in a way that is wholly incidental to Managing Assets; and how does that interact with the Category 2 test for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal) and the requirement that dealing activities are not limited in scope?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person should be treated as falling within Category 3C (rather than Category 3A) if it carries out Dealing in Investments as Agent only in a manner that is wholly incidental to Managing Assets, and it otherwise meets the Category 3C conditions. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Category 3C applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises one or more specified Regulated Activities, including Managing Assets, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] The “wholly incidental” linkage is important because, although Category 3A is generally determined by authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent (and the absence of certain other authorisations), the text expressly directs that incidental Dealing in Investments as Agent alongside Managing Assets results in Category 3C treatment. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Separately, Category 2 is triggered by authorisation for Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), combined with dealing activities that are not limited in scope, and the firm not meeting Categories 1 or 5. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Therefore, to remain in Category 3C, the firm must not meet the Category 2 criteria while satisfying the Category 3C conditions tied to Managing Assets and the exclusion of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B and 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]
target_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.

question: If a Listed Entity signs a deal to issue Equity Securities but says it will only go ahead if holders approve, can it still issue the Equity Securities without that approval, especially if the deal would put it over the maximum number allowed under the new-issue limit?
gold_answer: No. If a Listed Entity relies on an agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approving the issue before it is made, the Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing the Equity Securities unless and until that approval has been obtained; it must not issue without such approval. Separately, the Listed Entity is also prohibited from issuing, or even agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the formula unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities. This means that where the proposed issue (or agreement) would exceed the calculated maximum, holder approval is required to avoid breaching the new-issue restriction, and the same approval is also the gating condition for any issuance under the conditional agreement. The approval is also relevant to how the limit is measured: issuances or agreements made with holder approval are carved out from “Relevant Issues,” and certain approved issuances can be counted in the “Base Amount,” which can affect the maximum number permitted. [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]
source_text: An agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approving the issue under Rule 9.7.1 before the issue is made.  If a Listed Entity relies on this exception, it must not issue the Equity Securities without such approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: For an Authorised Person, how does the scope of its Financial Services Permission determine whether it is classified in Category 1 versus Category 3B, and what exclusionary category tests must be satisfied in each case?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person’s category turns on which Regulated Activities its Financial Services Permission authorises and on specified exclusion tests. For Category 1, the permission must authorise the firm to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm must not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance emphasises that this specific authorisation is determinative even if the firm is also authorised for other Regulated Activities [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. By contrast, Category 3B applies where the permission authorises one or more of the Regulated Activities of Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund) or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5; the guidance similarly notes that the custody-for-a-Fund or trustee authorisation, together with the absence of authorisation for certain other activities, is determinative even if other activities are also authorised [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe].
source_text:
Category 3B
An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of:
(i)	Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or
(ii)	Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and
(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5.
Guidance
A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already gave all the required details when it first disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates, what does it need to do in a later update so it can avoid repeating those details, and what key warning statement still has to appear clearly next to the estimates?
