gold_answer: In a later update, the Mining Reporting Entity can avoid repeating the full set of required details that normally must be included when disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation (for example, the sources and dates, reliability, summaries of work and assumptions, and the named Competent Person statement) only if it is relying on an earlier disclosure that already met the applicable requirements. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] The update must (1) refer back to that earlier compliant disclosure, and (2) include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that the earlier information still applies and that there is no new material information or data that affects either how reliable/understandable the estimates are or the entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Even with that shortcut, the update still has to show a statement that is at least as prominent and placed close to the estimates, covering the key warnings for Non-Equivalent Estimates—namely that they are not disclosed under a Mining Reporting Standard, a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and it is uncertain they will ever become reportable as such after further evaluation/exploration. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: When an Investigator uses written notice to require a person (including a Person Under Investigation or any other person) to permit entry to business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy Documents, what notice is required and can the Investigator proceed without giving advance notice where prior notice could prejudice the investigation?
gold_answer: An Investigator can require entry to a person’s business premises during normal business hours for inspection and copying of Documents by issuing a written notice that includes that requirement. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Separately, when exercising the power to enter business premises under section 206(1)(e) of FSMR, the Investigator must give written notice that the power is being exercised, but the text makes clear there is no obligation to provide that notice in advance. [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980] In practice, this means the Investigator’s written notice can function as the mechanism to require the person to permit entry during normal business hours, while still allowing the Investigator to avoid prior notice where appropriate. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The Investigator may decide not to provide prior notice of an inspection in circumstances where giving advance notice could prejudice the investigation. [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980] Accordingly, the compliance expectation is that written notice will be given, but it need not be delivered ahead of time, particularly where advance warning could undermine the investigative purpose of inspecting and copying Documents on the premises. [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]
source_text: Power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents . The Investigator will give written notice of the exercise of the power to enter business premises under section 206(1)(e) of FSMR. However, there is no requirement for an Investigator to give notice of the exercise of this power in advance. There may be circumstances when the Investigator considers it appropriate not to provide prior notice of an inspection, for example where the provision of prior notice may prejudice the investigation.

question: When a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 seeks the Regulator’s consent to release that holding lock so holders of Restricted Securities can accept an offer (or transfer/cancel Securities) under a Takeover, what specific preconditions must be satisfied for the Regulator to provide consent, including the acceptance threshold and any written agreement to immediately re-impose the holding lock if the Takeover does not complete or Securities are not acquired?
gold_answer: The Regulator may consent to the release of a holding lock managed under Rule 9.6.9 to allow holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or to transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover. [#TGT:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67] However, the Regulator will not provide that consent unless the applicable conditions for the relevant transaction structure are met. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] Where there is an offer for Securities, the offer must cover all Ordinary Securities, or if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, it must cover all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] In addition, holders of at least half of the Securities (to which the offer relates) that are not Restricted Securities must have accepted the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 is immediately re-imposed for each Security not bought by the offeror under the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the Takeover is conducted by way of a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held must agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 is immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]
source_text:
Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator will not provide its consent under Rule 9.6.11 unless, to the extent to which they are applicable, all the following requirements are met:
(1)	where there is an offer for Securities:
(a)	the offer is for all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all the Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities;
(b)	holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities, to which the offer relates, have accepted; and
(c)	if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder agree in writing that the holding lock (imposed under Rule 9.6.9) be immediately re-imposed for each Security that is not bought by the offeror under the offer; and
(2)	where the offer is to be conducted by way of a ‘scheme’, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
target_text: Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange wants to admit Units in a closed-ended Investment Fund to trading, what must its Business Rules achieve, and what closed-ended fund checks should it use to decide whether trading will be fair, orderly and efficient?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange can admit Financial Instruments to trading only if its Business Rules ensure that instruments admitted to trading are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] For Units in a closed-ended Investment Fund, the way it should judge whether that “fair, orderly and efficient” standard is met is by taking into account two specific fund features: how widely the Units are distributed to the public, and whether the value of the Units is made sufficiently transparent to investors. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131] The value-transparency element can be satisfied, for this assessment, either through publication of information about the Fund’s investment strategy or through periodic publication of a net asset value. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131] Accordingly, the Business Rules should not just state the general trading-quality requirement; they should be applied through an admission review that explicitly checks those closed-ended fund factors so the Recognised Investment Exchange can conclude the Units will trade fairly, orderly and efficiently on its market. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]
source_text:
Units in collective investment funds
When assessing whether Units are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner for the purposes of Rule 3.9.1, a Recognised Investment Exchange shall take the following aspects into account:
(a)	For an open-ended Collective Investment Fund:
(i)	the distribution of those Units to the public;
(ii)	whether there are appropriate market-making arrangements, or whether the Fund Manager provides appropriate alternative arrangements for investors to redeem the Units; and
(iii)	whether the value of the units is made sufficiently transparent to investors by means of the periodic publication of the net asset value.
(b)	For a closed-ended Investment Fund:
(i)	the distribution of those Units to the public; and
(ii)	whether the value of the Units is made sufficiently transparent to investors, either by publication of information on the Fund's investment strategy or by the periodic publication of a net asset value.
target_text:
Admission to trading
In order to admit Financial Instruments to trading, a Recognised Investment Exchange must satisfy the following requirements, save and except for Recognised Investment Exchanges which only admit to trading Derivatives, in which case only (a), (b), (c) and (i) apply:
(a)	A Recognised Investment Exchange’s Business Rules must be clear and transparent in relation to the admission of Financial Instruments to trading on any market operated by it.
(b)	The Business Rules must ensure that all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on any market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner.
(c)	The Business Rules must ensure that:
(i)	all Financial Instruments other than Derivatives admitted to trading on a market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are freely negotiable; and
(ii)	all contracts for Derivatives admitted to trading on a regulated market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are designed so as to allow for their orderly pricing as well as for the existence of effective settlement conditions.
(d)	For the purposes of meeting the requirements in Rule 3.9.1(c)(ii), a Recognised Investment Exchange must include in its Business Rules, or its Business Rule procedures, contract design specifications relating to Derivative contracts traded on its market which, at a minimum, include:
(i)	minimum price fluctuations (price ticks);
(ii)	maximum price fluctuations (daily price limits), if any;
(iii)	last trading day;
(iv)	settlement or delivery procedures as applicable;
(v)	trading months;
(vi)	position limits, if any;
(vii)	reportable levels; and
(viii)	trading hours.
(e)	The Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain effective arrangements to verify that Issuers of Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a market operated by it comply with its disclosure obligations.
(f)	The Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain arrangements to assist users of a market operated by it to obtain access to information made public under its disclosure obligations.
(g)	The Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain arrangements regularly to review whether the Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a market operated by it comply with the admission requirements for those Financial Instruments.
(h)	The Business Rules must provide that where a Recognised Investment Exchange, without obtaining the consent of the Issuer, admits to trading on a market operated by it a Financial Instrument which has been admitted to trading on another market, the Recognised Investment Exchange:
(i)	must inform the Issuer of that Financial Instrument as soon as is reasonably practicable; and
(ii)	may not require the Issuer of that Financial Instrument to demonstrate compliance with its disclosure obligations.
(i)	The Business Rules must provide that where a Recognised Investment Exchange, without obtaining the consent of the Issuer, admits to trading on an MTF operated by it a Financial Instrument which has been admitted to trading on a market, it may not require the Issuer of that Financial Instrument to demonstrate compliance with its disclosure obligations.
(j)	A Recognised Investment Exchange must comply with the requirements of Rule 3.11 where it admits to trading on a market operated by it a Financial Instrument, the value of which is determined by reference to an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency.

question: When the Regulator is considering whether to refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (in whole or in part) while also proposing to take Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch pursuant to section 78(5), how do the preconditions for taking Resolution Action in respect of an ADGM Branch interact with the refusal ground that the Resolution Conditions have not been met?
gold_answer: If the Regulator proposes to take Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch pursuant to section 78(5), it may refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (in whole or in part) where it is satisfied that the Resolution Conditions have not been met for the relevant entity. [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] For an ADGM Branch, those Resolution Conditions include that the Regulator is satisfied the branch is failing or likely to fail, that (considering timing and other relevant circumstances) it is not reasonably likely that other action by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or the Non-ADGM Institution will prevent that failure or likely failure, and that applying a Resolution Tool is in the public interest. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] In addition, the Regulator must be satisfied about the Non-ADGM Institution’s status regarding Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings—either it is not subject (and not likely within a reasonable timeframe to become subject) to such measures, or it is subject to Foreign Resolution Action and a specified circumstance applies. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] Accordingly, if any of these ADGM-Branch-specific conditions are not met, that shortfall can support refusal of recognition under the ground tied to unmet Resolution Conditions in the section 78(5) context. [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]
source_text:
A Resolution Action may be taken in respect of an ADGM Branch only if the Regulator is satisfied that the following conditions are met—
(a)	the ADGM Branch is failing or is likely to fail;
(b)	having regard to timing and other relevant circumstances, it is not reasonably likely that any action will be taken by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution that will prevent the failure or likely failure of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution;
(c)	the application of a Resolution Tool is in the public interest; and
(d)	the Non-ADGM Institution is—
(i)	not subject to, and not likely in a reasonable timeframe to be subject to, any Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings; or
(ii)	subject to Foreign Resolution Action, and one of the circumstances referred to in section 78(2) applies in respect of the Non-ADGM Institution.

question: Credit RWA is made up of several parts. For the part that comes from securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), what steps must an Authorised Person follow to calculate the RWA and then include it in the overall Credit RWA total?
gold_answer: Credit RWA for an Authorised Person is defined as a sum that includes its RWA for all its securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures) as one of the components that make up the total [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]. To produce that SE component so it can be added into the overall Credit RWA sum, the Authorised Person must apply the SE calculation process: it must determine the exposure value for each SE Exposure using the specified exposure measurement methodology and taking into account any applicable CRM; it must then assign an applicable Credit Quality Grade for the SE Exposure under the relevant rules; and it must calculate the RWA amount for each SE Exposure using the stated formula that multiplies the exposure value by the applicable risk weight (except where the SE Exposure must instead be included as a deduction from a component of Capital Resources). After calculating RWA amounts for each SE Exposure, the Authorised Person must add them up across all SE Exposures and then add those amounts to the RWA amounts calculated for its Early Amortisation Exposures [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646].
source_text:
The Credit RWA of an Authorised Person is the sum of:
(a)	its risk weighted assets (RWA) for all its Credit Risk Exposures (referred to in these Rules as "CR Exposures") calculated in accordance with Rules 4.8.2 and 4.8.3;
(b)	its RWA for all its securitisation Exposures (referred to in these Rules as "SE Exposures") calculated in accordance with Rule 4.8.4 and Section 4.14; and
(c)	its RWA for its Counterparty Risk Exposures as calculated in accordance with Sections A4.6 to A4.8.

question: When a person is compelled to attend an interview under section 206, what notice must be given before the interview, and what grounds are expressly not a reasonable excuse for refusing to answer questions or provide information/documents under the related requirements?
gold_answer: A person who is required to attend an interview must first be given written notice requiring their attendance to answer questions at that interview. [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda] Once a requirement to answer questions (and, where applicable, to permit inspection/copying or to give/produce information or a Document) is made under sections 201, 203, or 206(1)(a), (b), (c) and (e), the person cannot treat certain concerns as a “reasonable excuse” for refusing or failing to comply. [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab] In particular, the person is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer questions on the basis that the answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty, or might reveal a communication made in confidence, with the confidentiality point being expressly subject to section 209(6). [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda] The same types of grounds—tending to incriminate the person or revealing a communication made in confidence (again subject to section 209(6))—are also stated not to be a reasonable excuse for refusing or failing to permit inspection/copying of information or a Document, or to give/produce (or procure the giving/production of) information or a Document, when those obligations arise under the specified sections. [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . A person required to attend an interview will first be provided with written notice requiring their attendance at the interview to answer questions. Pursuant to section 206(5) of FSMR, an interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question on the basis that their answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section 209(6) of FSMR).
target_text:
Subject to section ‎210‎(3), it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to—
(a)	permit inspection and copying of any information or Document;
(b)	give or produce, or procure the giving or production of, any information or Document; or
(c)	answer questions;
pursuant to any requirement under sections ‎201, ‎203 and ‎206‎(1)‎(a), ‎(b), ‎(c) and ‎(e) on the grounds that any such information or Document or answer, as the case may be—
(d)	might tend to incriminate the person; or
(e)	is, or contains, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section ‎209‎(6)).

question: When a FinTech Participant cannot meet the applicable criteria, in what circumstances must it stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab, and how does the Regulator’s own-initiative variation or cancellation of a Financial Services Permission affect the timing of that cessation?
gold_answer: Where the FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the applicable criteria, it must cease carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7]. The timing is bounded by two alternative triggers: (i) the expiry of its RegLab FSP, reflecting the stated two-year validity period, or (ii) an earlier point in time if the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7]. The TARGET clarifies the relevant scope of that second trigger by identifying that the variation or cancellation is one undertaken on the initiative of the Regulator, and that it concerns variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a]. Accordingly, the obligation to stop the Regulated Activity applies once the FinTech Participant cannot meet the criteria, and the cessation deadline is either at permission expiry or at the point the Regulator, acting on its own initiative, varies or cancels the Financial Services Permission, whichever occurs first in practice.
source_text: Two-year validity period. If the FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the above criteria, it will be required to cease carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab.  The deadline for ceasing the Regulated Activity will be upon the expiry of its RegLab FSP, or at such time as the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP in accordance with section 33 of the FSMR.  Please refer to section 8 below for more details.
target_text: Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission. Variation or cancellation on initiative of the Regulator

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses material estimates of Contingent Resources that have not previously been disclosed, what must it include about the permits or licences it holds, and how does this requirement align with the content obligations that apply when it makes a disclosure under the other disclosure trigger?
gold_answer: Where a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses estimates of Contingent Resources that are material and have not previously been disclosed, it must ensure the disclosure identifies the types of permits or licences it holds that are relevant to the disclosed estimates of Contingent Resources [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec]. This aligns with the separate obligation that applies when a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under the other disclosure trigger, which likewise requires the disclosure to contain the types of permits or licences held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity relating to the estimates [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]. In practice, the Entity should ensure that, in both contexts, the permit/licence description is tied to the specific estimates being disclosed (i.e., connected to the estimates rather than provided generically). For the new, material Contingent Resources disclosure, this permits/licences element sits alongside additional required content (such as the basis for confirming potentially moveable Petroleum and the determination of a discovery, and descriptions of estimation method and key contingencies), but the permits/licences identification remains a mandatory standalone inclusion.

question: If an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission, what risk weight must it apply, and when can it recognise the CRM effect of a Credit Derivative for that exposure?
gold_answer: Where the Authorised Person’s CR Exposure is to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission, it must apply a 0% risk weight to that CR Exposure [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]. If, in addition, the Authorised Person wants to recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative for that exposure, it may do so only if the Credit Derivative is provided by one of the permitted types of entities [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b]. Those permitted providers are: a central government or central bank; an MDB; an International Organisation; a PSE; banks and Securities firms that qualify for inclusion in the bank asset class; or another entity that has an external credit assessment from a recognised credit rating agency that maps to a Credit Quality Grade 3 or better. In practice, this means the risk-weight outcome for the specified CR Exposures is fixed at 0%, but any Credit Derivative CRM recognition is still gated by who provides the derivative.
target_text: Multilateral development bank (MDB) asset class. An Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission.

question: If someone files a Supplementary Prospectus, does that automatically mean they have to pay an extra fee, or can the Regulator only charge a supplementary fee when it expects substantial extra cost or work—like it can for other filings, applications, authorisations, or on-going supervision?
gold_answer: Filing a Supplementary Prospectus does not automatically result in an extra fee. The specific rule states that the filing itself does not trigger payment unless the review of the Supplementary Prospectus will require the Regulator to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort when conducting its review; only in that situation may the Regulator require payment of a supplementary fee [#SRC:cec237a1-c364-4ed0-9197-dcac6160defb]. The general supplementary-fee provision uses the same threshold—where the Regulator expects substantial additional costs or substantial additional effort—and explains that this permission can apply in a wider set of situations, including dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Putting both together, a Supplementary Prospectus filing is treated as a type of filing that normally carries no extra charge, but it can become chargeable if the Regulator anticipates that reviewing it will materially increase the resources needed, consistent with the broader approach to supplementary fees.
source_text: The filing of a Supplementary Prospectus does not trigger the payment of a fee unless the review of the Supplementary Prospectus will require the Regulator to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort when conducting its review, in which event the Regulator may require payment of a supplementary fee in accordance with Rule 1.2.4.
target_text:
Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: When an Authorised Person provides any Regulated Activities, what must it do to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest, and how do the additional requirements that apply to the Authorised Person affect this obligation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must take all reasonable steps to identify conflicts of interest that arise or may arise in the course of providing any Regulated Activities, including conflicts between the Authorised Person (and its managers, Employees and Clients, or persons linked to them by control) and a Client, as well as conflicts between one Client and another Client, and it must do so as part of complying with Principle 7 [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319]. In parallel, the requirements applying to the Authorised Person under the referenced rule operate in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder, meaning the Authorised Person must treat the conflict-identification duty as cumulative with other applicable obligations rather than a standalone requirement [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. The Source further indicates that, once actual or potential conflicts are identified, the Authorised Person is required to prevent or manage them, reinforcing that reasonable-step identification is not an end in itself but part of a broader conflicts framework [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759].
source_text: The requirements in this Rule ‎6.4.2 apply to an Authorised Person in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder. For example, an Authorised Person is required to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them under GEN 3.3.21-3.3.24. An Authorised Person must also have adequate procedures and controls when it prepares or publishes Investment Research.
target_text:
Conflicts of Interest: An Authorised Person must comply with Principle 7 as outlined in Rule ‎2.2.7, taking all reasonable steps to identify conflicts of interest between:
(1)	the Authorised Person, including its managers, Employees and Clients, or any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control; or
(2)	one Client of the Authorised Person and another Client,
that arises or may arise in the course of the Authorised Person providing any Regulated Activities.

question: If a Relevant Person wants to hire a service provider to do CDD and will rely on an eKYC System, what must the Relevant Person do before appointment, and what should the assurance assessment try to confirm about the eKYC System?
gold_answer: Before appointing a service provider to undertake CDD, a Relevant Person must carry out an initial assurance assessment to evaluate whether the service provider is suitable, and must make sure the service provider’s obligations are clearly written down in a binding agreement [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752]. If the arrangement involves using an eKYC System, the assurance assessment should be designed to seek to establish that the eKYC System is reliable and independent, and that it allows the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4]. This links the “suitability” check on the service provider to the quality and governance of the eKYC System that will support CDD, so the Relevant Person can be confident the overall setup supports regulatory compliance. As part of performing the assurance work, the Relevant Person should also consider applying guidance on assurance standards issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard setting bodies, to help structure and evidence the assessment [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4].
source_text: When undertaking an assurance assessment of an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule ‎9.3.1A, a Relevant Person should seek to establish that the eKYC System is reliable and independent, and allows the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator. In addition, a Relevant Person should consider applying guidance on assurance standards issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard setting bodies.
target_text: Prior to appointing a service provider to undertake CDD, a Relevant Person must undertake an initial assurance assessment to evaluate the suitability of the service provider and must ensure that the service provider's obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement.

question: What does a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity have to put in its quarterly report (including what to say if there were no activities and what to cover about controlled entities), and how soon after the quarter ends does it have to disclose the Rule 12.13.1 report?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity’s quarterly report has two linked requirements: it must include specific Petroleum-related information for the quarter (with a consolidated scope where relevant), and it must be disclosed within a set time after the quarter ends. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1] On content, the report is for each quarter of the financial year and must cover the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, using a consolidated basis if applicable. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] It must describe activities relating to Petroleum Exploration (or clearly state there were no Exploration activities) and production and development (or state there were no mining production and development activities). [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] It also must summarize expenditure for Exploration and for production and development, list Petroleum Tenements held at quarter-end with location and percentage interest (including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements), and identify Petroleum Tenements acquired or disposed of during the quarter (including those beneficial interests) with their location. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] Separately, the report must address the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months unless included in the annual report, and it must indicate when the prior and next such disclosures were and are due. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] The Rule 12.13.1 report must be disclosed no later than one month after the end of the quarter. [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1]
source_text: Quarterly Reports – Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entities. A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose the report required by Rule 12.13.1 no later than one month after the end of the quarter.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity is permitted to disclose forecast financial information derived from a Production Target in connection with its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or material Mining Project(s), what specific content must that disclosure include regarding the assumptions used and the underlying Production Target?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may disclose forecast financial information derived from a Production Target in relation to either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s) [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]. When it makes that type of disclosure, the disclosure must include detailed information about the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions employed, plus all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must include a statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In addition, the disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required to be provided for that Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, can the Payment Service Provider still charge for extra information the user asks for (like information beyond Section 19.2 or sent in a different way than the Framework Contract), and can the parties also switch off the “charges for information” rules—what must they do to make that happen?
gold_answer: Yes—there are two related contracting options, and the second one depends on the Payment Service User not being a Natural Person. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] First, the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User may agree on charges for information that the Payment Service User requests when the information is extra compared with what Section 19.2 requires, is provided more often than Section 19.2 sets out, or is delivered using a communication method other than the one specified in the Framework Contract. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] Second, if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing that Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (the rules identified as dealing with charges for information) do not apply. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Putting these together, the parties can either (a) keep the information-charging approach and set the price for those qualifying requests, or (b) where eligible, formally document in writing that the specific “charges for information” rules are not applicable between them. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]
target_text:
The Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User may agree on charges for any information which is provided at the request of the Payment Service User where such information is:
(a)	additional to the information required to be provided or made available by Section 19.2;
(b)	provided more frequently than is specified in Section 19.2; or
(c)	transmitted by means of communication other than those specified in the Framework Contract.

question: If a Listed Entity wants to issue Equity Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme but would otherwise go over the allowed 20% limit, what must the notice of meeting include so the holders of Ordinary Securities can approve the issue and the Listed Entity is not prohibited from issuing above the calculated maximum?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number calculated under the 20% Base Amount formula (after subtracting Relevant Issues) unless it first obtains approval from the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. If the Listed Entity is using an Employee Incentive Scheme and is seeking that holder approval as the basis to proceed (within the specified three-year lookback described for scheme issues), the notice of meeting has mandatory content that cannot be left out. Specifically, it must include: (1) a summary of the terms of the scheme; (2) the number of Securities already issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List, or since the date of the last approval under the relevant approval route; and (3) the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme after the approval is given [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113]. Including these items supports the validity of the holder approval that is required to avoid the prohibition on issuing above the calculated maximum.
source_text:
An issue of Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme if within three years before the issue date:
(a)	in the case of a scheme established before the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List – a summary of the terms of the scheme and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme were set out in in its Approved Prospectus or documents lodged with the Regulator under Rule 2.4.3; or
(b)	the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities have approved the issue of Equity Securities under the scheme as an exception to Rule 9.7.1.  The notice of meeting must have included:
(i)	a summary of the terms of the scheme;
(ii)	the number of Securities issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List, or the date of the last approval under this Rule; and
(iii)	the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme following the approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If an Authorised Person is below its Combined Buffer Requirement, what steps does it have to take to work out the maximum distributable amount (what profits to use and what quartile factor applies), and what must it avoid doing until it has done the calculation and notified the Regulator?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must first calculate its maximum distributable amount and treat that calculation (plus notifying the Regulator) as a prerequisite before it carries out certain distributions, remuneration steps, or capital-instrument payments. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] To calculate the maximum distributable amount, it multiplies a specific profit total by a factor tied to the quartile position of its CET1 Capital that is not used to meet the Capital Requirement (including any Individual Capital Requirement). [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The profit total is limited to interim or year-end profits that were excluded from CET1 Capital and that built up after the most recent profit distribution and after any actions referred to in Rule 3.19.3(b). [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The factor is set by quartile: 0 (first), 0.2 (second), 0.4 (third), or 0.6 (fourth). [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] Until it has calculated the amount and notified the Regulator, it must not make CET1-related distributions, create obligations for variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, pay variable remuneration where the obligation arose while it was failing the buffer, or make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]
target_text:
Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and
(b)	ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7:
(i)	make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: Where an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and has published a Prospectus, what must the Issuer (or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus) do if, after the Prospectus is issued, a significant change occurs or a material mistake/inaccuracy or significant new matter arises, and what baseline prospectus requirement anchors this obligation?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Issuer’s baseline obligation is to publish a Prospectus when it wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] Once that Prospectus has been issued, if at any time afterward there is a significant change in information, a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting a matter in the Prospectus, or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for issuing the Prospectus must issue a supplementary prospectus. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The supplementary prospectus must (i) set out details of the relevant change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and (ii) meet the requirements referenced in section 62(1). [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The timing trigger is explicitly “after the issue of a Prospectus” and applies whenever the specified events occur, meaning the duty is ongoing for the period after issuance rather than limited to a single update point. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] This supplementary-prospectus duty is therefore an extension of the initial prospectus publication requirement that applies to Offers of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]
source_text: Regulatory treatment of tokens deemed to be Securities. The requirements for Offers of Securities fall under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (“MKT”). When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, these requirements include, for example, the obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR.
target_text:
Prospectus requirement. Obligation to issue a supplementary prospectus
If at any time after the issue of a Prospectus there is a significant change in, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting any matter contained in the Prospectus or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus shall issue a supplementary prospectus which—
(a)	provides details of the change, mistake, inaccuracy or new matter; and
(b)	complies with the requirements in section ‎62‎(1).

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, how must it reflect the collateral’s credit risk mitigation effects in its RWA calculation process, including how it determines the Exposure value (E) and the applicable risk weight for the collateralised and uncollateralised portions?
gold_answer: In calculating RWA for CR Exposures, an Authorised Person must determine an Exposure value (E) for each on- and off-balance sheet asset using the applicable exposure measurement methodology and must recognise the effects of any applicable CRM as part of that process [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]. Where the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, it is permitted to recognise the CRM effects by splitting the CR Exposure into two components: a collateralised portion and an uncollateralised portion [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb]. For the collateralised portion, E is set to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the applicable risk weight is the CRW that applies to that collateral as if the Authorised Person had a direct exposure to it. For the uncollateralised portion, E is the original E of the CR Exposure reduced by the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the applicable risk weight is the CRW that applies to the obligor. The resulting RWA amounts are then calculated using the E × CRW approach and aggregated across exposures as required [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368].
source_text:
Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows:
(a) 	break down the Exposure into -
(i) 	a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and
(ii) 	an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral;
and
(b) 	for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use:
(i) 	for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and
(ii) 	for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has an operating mine(s) and its Production Target is built only from Ore Reserves plus Measured Mineral Resources (and maybe Indicated Mineral Resources, but Indicated Mineral Resources are not what makes the project viable), does it still need to include the assumptions and proportion breakdown details required for a disclosure made under Rule 11.8.2, even though Rule 11.8.3 does not apply?
gold_answer: Yes. If the Production Target for an operating mine(s) is wholly based on Ore Reserves, or on Ore Reserves together with Measured Mineral Resources, or on Ore Reserves together with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources (with Indicated Mineral Resources not being the determining factor in project viability), the Mining Reporting Entity does not have to make its disclosure comply with Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:1d86427d-4a34-4179-bd16-1f64e7ef8560] But when the entity is making a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2, it still must provide the specific information that Rule 11.8.2 requires about the Production Target. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] That includes disclosing all material economic assumptions used to determine the Production Target, or if those assumptions are commercially sensitive, stating that and explaining the methodology used to determine them, and also disclosing all other material assumptions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If forecast commodity prices were used, it must also say they were reached on reasonable grounds. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] In addition, it must show the proportions of the Production Target that are based on the listed categories, including Probable/Proved Ore Reserves and Indicated/Measured Mineral Resources. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure is not required to comply with Rule 11.8.3 where a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based upon:
(1)	Ore Reserves;
(2)	a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or
(3)	a combination of Ore Reserves; and
(a)	Measured Mineral Resources; and/or
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: When Restricted Securities are subject to a holding lock, how must a Listed Entity ensure the lock is not released without the Regulator’s prior written consent, and in what circumstances may the Regulator permit the party managing the holding lock to release it to facilitate actions under a Takeover or Merger?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must implement controls that align the holding-lock undertaking with the Regulator’s consent framework: it must obtain an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, and submit that undertaking to the Regulator within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. The undertaking must require the relevant entity to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities it holds and not to release that holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent, so the Listed Entity’s obligation is both to secure the undertaking and to ensure the lock-release condition is embedded and observed [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. In parallel, the Regulator has discretion to consent to a party that is managing a holding lock releasing the holding lock in the context of a Takeover or Merger, where doing so enables holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer or to transfer or cancel Securities under a Takeover [#SRC:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67].
source_text: Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: Where the Listing Authority has completed an enquiry into a complaint or allegation of non-compliance and concludes the information is accurate, constitutes Inside Information, and is not exempt from Disclosure under Rule 7.2.2, what action may it require from the Reporting Entity under Rule 7.2.1, and if it also considers the information should have been Disclosed earlier, how does the Listing Authority typically handle Disclosure of any ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response once that response has been received and reviewed?
gold_answer: If, following its enquiry, the Listing Authority decides the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and does not fall within the Rule 7.2.2 exemption, it will request that the Reporting Entity make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] If the Listing Authority also considers the information should have been Disclosed earlier, it may issue an ‘aware letter’ (or take other relevant action). [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] In the event an ‘aware letter’ is issued, the Listing Authority’s usual practice—after the Reporting Entity’s response has been received and reviewed—is to Disclose both the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response together. [#TGT:f4e70987-8287-425e-a207-54a123dfa6f4] This joint Disclosure is intended to ensure the market in the Listed Entity’s Securities is informed that the Listing Authority has made enquiries about the timeliness of the Reporting Entity’s Disclosures and is also aware of the Reporting Entity’s response to those enquiries. [#TGT:f4e70987-8287-425e-a207-54a123dfa6f4]
source_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Complaints or allegations of non-compliance by Reporting Entities
If, as a result of the enquiry, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within exemption from Disclosure provided by Rule 7.2.2, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1.  If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
target_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Aware Letters
When a Reporting Entity’s response has been received and reviewed by the Listing Authority, both the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response will usually be Disclosed together by the Listing Authority, so that the market in the Listed Entity’s Securities is aware that the Listing Authority has made enquiries of the Reporting Entity about the timeliness of its Disclosures, and of the Reporting Entity’s response to those enquiries.

question: What does an Authorised Person have to do to work out its countercyclical buffer and then keep the required buffer amount in CET1 Capital at all times?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must both calculate and maintain the buffer in CET1 Capital. On the calculation side, it must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures are located [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. That produces the required buffer amount for this buffer type. On the holding side, the Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, so it is not enough to compute the figure; the firm must continuously hold CET1 Capital in at least that amount once determined [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]. Together, these requirements mean the firm must follow the specified method to quantify the countercyclical buffer and then ensure its CET1 Capital remains sufficient to cover the resulting required buffer amount on an ongoing basis.
source_text: An Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, as calculated in accordance with Rule 3.18.4.
target_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.

question: If a Fund Manager tells its auditor in writing to audit the Fund’s financial statements using IAASB standards, what does the Fund Manager then need to make sure the auditor actually says in the Fund Auditor’s Report (including anything that can be about a Sub-Fund and the annual accounting period)?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager’s responsibilities span both the engagement step and the content-control step: it must give a written requirement to its auditor to carry out an audit of the Fund’s financial statements under the relevant IAASB standards and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on those audited statements. [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579] After that, when arranging for the report to be produced, the Fund Manager must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements in the Fund Auditor’s Report. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] These include whether the financial statements were properly prepared using the financial reporting standards the Fund adopted under FUNDS, and whether the statements give a true and fair view of the Fund’s financial position. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The true-and-fair view must cover net income and net gains or losses of the Fund Property (or, if applicable, the Fund Property attributable to the Sub-Fund) for the annual accounting period, and the financial position of the Fund or Sub-Fund at the end of that period. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The Auditor must also state if proper accounting records have not been kept or if the statements do not match records/returns or do not comply with applicable reporting standards, confirm whether it received all needed information and explanations, address consistency of the Directors’ report or Fund Manager’s report with the financial statements, and include any other matter required by FUNDS. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]
source_text:
Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: If Restricted Securities are issued and then a Takeover is proposed, what must the Listed Entity submit within two Business Days, and what extra conditions must be met before the Regulator will consent to releasing the holding lock (including what happens if the offer is conditional or the deal is done by scheme)?
gold_answer: After Restricted Securities are issued, the Listed Entity must quickly put the holding lock framework in place and then, if a Takeover or Merger later requires a release, satisfy the Regulator’s consent conditions for that transaction type. Within two Business Days after the issue, the Listed Entity must obtain an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable, and submit that undertaking to the Regulator; the undertaking must be to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by that entity and not to release it without the Regulator’s prior written consent. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] For the Regulator to give consent in a Takeover or Merger, the required conditions depend on whether the deal is an offer or a scheme. If it is an offer, the offer must cover all Ordinary Securities (or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all Securities in the same class), and at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities (to which the offer relates) must have accepted. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must sign a written agreement to immediately re-impose the holding lock for each Security not bought under the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the deal is by scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity must sign a written agreement to immediately re-impose the holding lock if the Takeover does not take effect. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]
source_text:
Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator will not provide its consent under Rule 9.6.11 unless, to the extent to which they are applicable, all the following requirements are met:
(1)	where there is an offer for Securities:
(a)	the offer is for all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all the Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities;
(b)	holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities, to which the offer relates, have accepted; and
(c)	if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder agree in writing that the holding lock (imposed under Rule 9.6.9) be immediately re-imposed for each Security that is not bought by the offeror under the offer; and
(2)	where the offer is to be conducted by way of a ‘scheme’, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: Does the Regulator have to get prior written consent before sharing Confidential Information with a criminal law enforcement agency for a criminal investigation or criminal proceedings, even if the agency is outside the U.A.E, or is that situation excluded from the usual consent limits?
gold_answer: Under the TARGET, the Regulator is generally not permitted to disclose Confidential Information through the listed disclosure routes unless specific conditions are met. Those conditions include getting prior written consent from the governmental or regulatory authority that originally provided the Confidential Information, and, where the Confidential Information is CRD Information, getting prior written consent from the EEA Competent Authority and disclosing only for any purpose specified in that consent [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c]. The SOURCE creates an important exception for a defined criminal law enforcement scenario: when the Regulator discloses Confidential Information to a criminal law enforcement agency (in the U.A.E or otherwise) for the purpose of a criminal investigation or criminal proceedings, that disclosure is not subject to the usual requirements referenced for consent and related conditions [#SRC:3ea3d5aa-2378-40cd-ab7a-f454859a385c]. Putting both together, the consent-based prohibition is the default, but it does not apply to the specific criminal law enforcement disclosure described in the SOURCE.
source_text: Disclosure to a criminal law enforcement agency. Importantly, disclosure of Confidential Information by the Regulator to a criminal law enforcement agency, whether in the U.A.E or otherwise, for the purpose of any criminal investigation or criminal proceedings under paragraph 199(1)(b)(v) is not subject to the requirements under section 199(2).
target_text:
Paragraphs (1)(b)(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi) and 1(c) do not permit the Regulator to disclose Confidential Information unless the conditions in paragraphs (a) and (b) are met –
(a)	where the Confidential Information (in whole or in part) originates in another governmental or regulatory authority, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise, the authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and
(b)	where the Confidential Information is CRD Information –
(i)	EEA Competent Authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and
(ii)	if such consent was given for a particular purpose, the disclosure by the Regulator is solely for that purpose.

question: Can a person ask the Appeals Panel to fully review a Regulator decision that affects them, and does the wider description also say that some non‑Part 21 decisions may still be referred even though operational decisions cannot?
gold_answer: A person can refer a decision to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review when the decision is made under these Regulations by the Regulator (or when the matter concerns Rules made by the Regulator) and it may affect the person’s rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect the person’s interests [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23]. The wider description of the referral framework adds two important clarifications. First, it indicates that operational decisions are excluded from the set of decisions that may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. Second, it explains that certain other decisions may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review even if they are not subject to the Part 21 procedure, and it provides the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers as an example [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. In practice, this means the person’s ability to refer depends on the decision’s adverse impact, with an operational-decision carve-out and an additional category of referable non‑Part 21 decisions.
source_text: Section 225(1) of FSMR provides that all of our decisions that may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person (except operational decisions) may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review. FSMR also specifies that certain other decisions, not subject to the Part 21 procedure, may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review (e.g., exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers).
target_text: Any decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator or Rules made by the Regulator which may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person, may be referred by that person to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review .

question: If someone is listed in the Rules made by the Regulator as liable for a Prospectus, do they still have to pay compensation for a misleading statement or missing required information when the buyer bought the Securities knowing the statement was wrong or knowing what was left out (or changed) or knowing about a new matter or inaccuracy?
gold_answer: Under the Prospectus compensation rule, any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to a person who acquired the Securities covered by that Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement, or because it omitted a material matter that was required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. But there is an important limitation: a Person does not incur liability where the person who incurred the loss acquired the Securities with knowledge that the statement was false, misleading, or deceptive, or with knowledge of the omitted matter (or the change), or with knowledge of the new matter or inaccuracy [#SRC:4ee654af-eec8-49f1-8813-6fb847d3eecb]. Put simply, even if the Prospectus has a misleading statement or a missing required item, the compensation obligation does not apply against that Person when the buyer purchased while already knowing the relevant problem (falsehood, omission/change, or new matter/inaccuracy) that is tied to the claimed loss.
source_text:
A Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if the Person incurring the loss acquired the Securities in question with knowledge:
(a)	that the statement was false, misleading, or deceptive;
(b)	of the omitted matter or of the change; or
(c)	of the new matter or inaccuracy.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.
